name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 4 October 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before we begin our work, I would like to express Parliament's condolences to the families of the victims of the floods in France, Spain and Italy in recent weeks. I would also like to express, on behalf of Parliament, our condolences to the families of the victims of the attacks on polling stations, which claimed dozens of lives and injured hundreds in Afghanistan. We stand shoulder to shoulder with the Afghan people, who have courageously responded to these cowards by going to the vote. I would also like to mention, one year after her death, Daphne Caruana Galizia, the brave Maltese journalist killed in her inquiries. This Parliament will always be at the forefront of defending the freedom of the press and the journalists who are the expression of it, everywhere in the world. That is why we are also urgently calling for a rigorous international investigation to clarify the circumstances surrounding the death of journalist and writer Jamal Khashoggi. We demand from the Saudi arabian authorities that the material executors and sponsors of this heinous crime be found and punished. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Minutes of the sitting of 4 October 2018 and the texts adopted have been distributed. Are there any comments? I declare the Minutes of the sitting of 4 October 2018 approved. ***

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a point of the regulation based on Articles 9 and 150 which concern procedures for lifting a Member's immunity. At the level of the Committee on Legal Affairs, nothing is being done to, first, to establish a minutes of hearing of the Member concerned; secondly, the establishment or registration of a possible pleading or defence note filed by the Member concerned or any documents possibly filed with the committee by that Member; thirdly, to allow the Member concerned to be aware, before his hearing, of the draft report on the lifting of his immunity since it is established afterwards; fourth, allow the Member to amend the draft report once he has received it. Article 150 of the Regulation does not allow the Member concerned to defend himself in front of his peers. This week, our colleague Nicolas Bay will have only two minutes to try to present Mr Briois' defence in plenary, all in violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, Articles 41, 42, 47 and 48, and the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 6, which enshrines the right of every person to be heard. Article 6, paragraph 1, of the European Convention on Human Rights, which is enshrined as a general principle of Community law, is applicable when a challenge to civil rights and obligations or a criminal charge is at stake. I therefore ask you, and this is my conclusion, to allow our colleague, Steve Briois, to be able to defend himself personally before this House when the debate requested by the ENL Group on the request to waive his parliamentary immunity will take place.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The rules are clear and have always been scrupulously followed for everyone. Members are heard in the JURI Committee with regard to immunity.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention and to the attention of the whole House that last Friday the President of Italian public television, Mr Marcello Foa, said in an interview with an Israeli newspaper the following sentence, that 'Soros financed a huge number of Members of the European Parliament, including the entire delegation of the Italian centre-left Democratic Party'. As far as we are concerned, as members of the Democratic Party we will take the steps we need to take to the courts to bring President Foa to court over these claims. However, Mr President, I believe that these statements not only affect the good repute and integrity of certain Members of this House, but the dignity and role of this Parliament, and I hope that you, Mr President, will defend this dignity and this role.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, one year ago an overwhelming majority of this House voted in favour of a resolution in order to fight against sexual harassment in the European Union and specifically also after cases of sexual harassment had come to the surface here in this House, and more than that, 130 000 citizens of the European Union signed a petition in order to implement this resolution. One year later, Mr President, this resolution has still not been fully implemented. The external audit as well as the review of the Committee Against Sexual Harassment have still not been finalised, and the mandatory trainings for MEPs have even been taken out of the Action Plan. I call on you, Mr Tajani: this is our common responsibility towards the people who work here in this Parliament, but also as a role model to all citizens in the European Union. Act on this. Make the European Union a front-runner in the fight against sexual harassment. The time is now. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: On. Post, is it for the same topic?

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, yes, it is about the same problem. As you might know, last month the MeToo European Parliament movement launched a blog which collects and publishes anonymous testimonies of victims of sexual harassment and sexual assault within the European Parliament: ‘MeTooEP.com’. The blog is intended to be a first port of call for victims, to provide solidarity and information, to raise awareness on what forms sexual harassment can take and to show victims that they are not alone. We need to break the culture of silence around sexual harassment. We need to support this movement of workers who are bravely sharing their stories, so we must fully support and implement the European Parliament resolution on combating sexual harassment and abuse in the EU adopted by a vast majority more than one year ago. I stand strongly with the MeToo European Parliament movement. We have to take this seriously and stop this culture.  (Applause)

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on Wednesday we are going to vote on the draft general budget of the European Union for 2019. The women who work here ask for their support for budget lines 13 59 and 13 60, which is the only thing that will allow concrete measures to be put in place against sexual harassment, already approved by this House a year ago. If these amendments were not adopted, the Resolution would have done no good. The European Parliament must be at the forefront of this. Society is ahead of us and points the way. So remember—and I'm done—support lines 13 59 and 13 60. Let's take our own commitments seriously and get rid of sexual harassment in this house. Companions, for all of you, we'll never walk alone again.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, as you know, the European Parliament is at the forefront of propaganda actions and activities in this area. As you have seen, a series of commercials have been presented for months, a series of messages, including visual messages inside the institution, to draw the attention of all members of parliament and all those who frequent our buildings to such a sensitive subject.  The Bureau has worked intensively and the working group chaired by Mr Morin-Chartier has given concrete answers. I would like to ask Mr Morin-Chartier if he would like to add something to explain briefly to our colleagues what has been done.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Mr President, thank you for allowing me to take stock at the beginning of the session on what we have been putting in place over the past year. There was a lot of work to be done and we have already ensured that training is put in place for Members of Parliament. I invite you, ladies and gentlemen, to take this training and to participate in its evolution. If you have any recommendations, advice, I will be very careful who will participate and who will provide advice on how to make it evolve. I would also like to say that we have established a code of conduct which will have to be signed by all Members. It didn't exist, so it's also a novelty. We have changed the rules of the committee to have a second parliamentary assistant. I am also delighted with the work of Carmela Scire, who came to work alongside Olivier Plumandon. So we've made progress. We have even changed the sanctions against Members, since today a Member who will be found harassing by the President will not only incur a sanction in accordance with the regulation, but he may also be obliged to pay the assistant's salary on his parliamentary envelope until the end of his contract. So know that we do not stand idly by. We are very careful to listen to complaints. Since September, September 14, I believe, we have set up a network of people we trust. What is very important is not to spread out what is happening and to make them hot throats, but to identify the people, the victims that we need to help, and punish the culprits. That is where we are working, and I thank you for taking note of that.

text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, we obviously fully support this request. text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I wanted to say that, basically, no one in this house is opposed to this debate being held and such a resolution being adopted. name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: author. – Mr President, it is almost three years since we signed the Paris Agreement and almost two years since its entry into force on 4 November 2016. A total of 181 out of the 197 parties to the Convention have already deposited with the UN their instruments of ratification to what may be qualified as the most significant international agreement of the decade. Undoubtedly climate change is one of the most important challenges facing humanity. The recently released report from the IPCC on global warming of 1.5°C indicates that climate risks are worse than we thought and that allowing global temperatures to rise by nearly 2°C is not safe. The Paris Agreement was a major step, but a lot more needs to be done to ensure that this agreement will deliver on its intentions. In this House we all know from our work on European legislation that if it’s hard to agree on a common set of policies, it is even harder to implement them in a meaningful way. We are five weeks away from the start of the 24th climate conference in Katowice and it is shaping up to be a race against time to prepare the so-called Paris ‘rule book’, which will govern how the climate agreement will actually be implemented. COP24 will be a key opportunity to take stock of progress made towards the agreement’s mitigation goal, and to inform the preparation and revision by 2020 of the parties’ nationally determined contributions for 2030. We will also learn from the Talanoa Dialogue, which took place throughout this year. The European Union and its Member States are the largest provider of public climate finance, but the actual pledges by developed countries fall far short of the collective goal of USD 100 billion per year. The suspension of the US contributions to the Green Climate Fund will substantially widen up a hole we have all been working hard to fill in. These are all pertinent questions. We look forward to the discussions today with both the Council and the Commission, who will be sitting on the negotiation table in Poland in five weeks’ time. As every year, in line with our commitment to the international climate process, the European Parliament will attend the Katowice Conference and follow the discussion and decisions made there. On Thursday this week we will adopt our resolution on the topic, which sets out the vision, concerns, expectations and aspirations of our institution. My colleagues will shortly present many of these in their interventions. But before I hand the floor to my colleagues, I would also like to raise the issue of biodiversity. Biodiversity decline is one of the biggest environmental challenges of our time. Unfortunately, the large majority of the 2020 Aichi Biodiversity Targets will not be met with the current trajectory of biodiversity loss. Given the intrinsic value of biodiversity and the essential contribution of ecosystem services to human wellbeing and economic prosperity, the protection of global biodiversity should receive the highest political attention. I would therefore urge the Commission and the Member States to commit to immediate, substantial and additional efforts on biodiversity conservation so as to meet the EU targets and halt the loss of biodiversity. I will leave it at that and conclude by saying that I look forward to a fruitful exchange with you all this afternoon, as well as a smooth cooperation between our institutions on these issues and, more specifically, in the run-up and during the climate negotiations in December.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. –  Mr. President, dear Commissioner Cañete, honourable Members of the Parliament, thank you very much for the opportunity to participate in this debate regarding two very important upcoming conferences. Allow me to first talk about the Katowice climate conference, before turning to the COP14 on Biological Diversity. As you are aware, only recently the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.0° above pre-industrial levels constituted yet another scientific finding on the negative impacts of climate change. The Council conclusions adopted on 9 October fully recognise the urgency of the global response to the threat. The European Union and its Member States can lead by example. We have more than two decades of experience in designing and implementing climate policies to drive the transition to a low-greenhouse-gas-emissions economy, and this transition is happening while boosting growth and jobs, thanks to the development of clean technologies and low or zero carbon energy. The European Union is forging ahead with the implementation of its nationally-determined contribution, and the European Parliament has played a leadership role in promoting the high level of European Union ambition. In the recent periods, we have reached political agreement on the key legislative pillars of the 2030 climate and energy framework, including the emissions trading system, the effort sharing regulation, land use and forestry and also on targets for renewables, energy efficiency and governance of the energy union. We are committed to continuing our efforts on climate action and agree with this House that a clear and comprehensive Paris rulebook is absolutely vital. Concluding our work at COP24 and making the Paris agreement operational is critical for its effective and comprehensive implementation by parties as well as for their credibility on the UNFCCC process. The Talanoa dialogue taking place throughout 2018 is the first opportunity since Paris to look at our collective efforts to limit global warming and what we have done concretely in terms of delivering on the commitments made as well as opportunities to enhance ambition. The European Union and its Member States see this dialogue as one of the key processes this year. The European Union organised an ‘EU for Talanoa’ event in Brussels in June with broad participation of policymakers and stakeholders. Member States, including Austria, organised their Talanoa events throughout the year. The European Union and its Member States are committed to continuing scaling up the mobilisation of international climate finance. The observed progression of EU climate finance over the past years is in line with the 2016 USD 100 billion roadmap. It represents a substantial contribution towards meeting this collective goal together with the other developed countries. Our public climate-specific finance has almost doubled in nominal terms over the last three years. The European Union and its Member States are collectively the largest provider of climate finance to developing countries, amounting to above EUR 20 billion in 2017. This figure includes contributions from public budgets and development finance institutions. It also includes 2.7 billion from the European Union budget and 1.9 billion from the European Investment Bank. The European Union is also a top contributor to multilateral funds and mechanisms. The EU and its Member States are the largest contributors to the Green Climate Fund, with a total of USD 4.7 billion committed, accounting for almost half of the total pledges made during the initial resource mobilisation. We have strongly supported the 7th replenishment of the Global Environment Facility with a commitment of about EUR 1.9 billion, accounting for over 50% of the total contributions.  Let me also stress the importance of making global finance flows consistent with a pathway towards low greenhouse gas emissions and climate-resilient development. Climate finance is a contribution towards this necessary global transition. The European Union is taking steps with its action plan in financing sustainable growth. As in the past, the Council counts on your sustained commitment. In this context I welcome also your resolution on the Katowice conference. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me now turn to the COP14 on biological diversity. The Council agrees with the Parliament that the protection of global biodiversity is an essential challenge. Like the Parliament, the Council is greatly concerned that the natural resource-base and ecosystem services on which humanity depends are at a high risk and that pressures driving biodiversity loss continue to increase. Increased efforts are thus necessary from all parties and stakeholders to fully implement the strategic plan for biodiversity 2011 to 2020 and achieve its Aichi Biodiversity Targets. The Council shares the Parliament’s view that we need an ambitious follow-up to the strategic plan for biodiversity beyond 2020. It stresses that this should be an overarching biodiversity framework that places biodiversity and ecosystem services high on political agendas, strengthening the implementation of the Biodiversity Convention and its protocols and of other biodiversity related multilateral environmental agreements and relevant SDGs. The new framework should pave the way towards the achievement of the 2050 vision on biodiversity. Another important element of the post-2020 Global Biodiversity Framework is resource mobilisation. It should include the mobilisation of resources from all sources, including from domestic resources and from the private sector, as well as the efficient and targeted use of available resources. As regards financial support for biodiversity, the Council believes that the Global Environment Facility Trust Fund has proven to be an important financing instrument for addressing drivers of environmental degradation and biodiversity loss and has a strong track record in delivering overall good project performance. The National Biodiversity strategies and action plans are and will remain the main instruments for implementing the Convention on Biodiversity and its protocols. Therefore it is crucial that Member States and all parties to the conventions increase their efforts to ensure their timely and effective implementation. Additional measures to complement and support the national strategies and action plans will be discussed on COP14 in Egypt, in the context of the post-2020 Global Biodiversity Framework.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for the opportunity to have this important debate as we look ahead to the preparations for the upcoming COP24 (Conference of the Parties) – the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in Katowice in Poland in December. The consequences of climate change are not a problem for others or for the future; impacts are already being felt – devastation by floods, wildfires, heatwaves and hurricanes, including on our continent. Two weeks ago, the Special Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on the impacts of global warming of 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels was released, and the report highlights the extreme urgency of climate action and the need to do more to reduce emissions in all sectors in order to limit global warming. Against this backdrop, the European Union envisages three broad deliverables for COP24, which are reflected also in the COP24 Council Conclusions adopted on 9 October and endorsed by the European Council last week. Firstly, we must conclude the Paris Work Programme, which concerns the detailed governance rules for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Securing this outcome is necessary to make the Paris Agreement operational. Secondly, at the political phase of the Talanoa Dialogue, Ministers will reflect on the adequacy of the current contributions and of international cooperation for climate action, and the insights from the recent IPCC 1.5° Special Report should be an important element in the discussion. The outcome of the Talanoa Dialogue should be a commitment of all parties to enhance their efforts to deliver the Paris commitments and to reflect on their level of ambition in view of informing the update or confirmation of the nationally-determined contributions by 2020 in line with the Paris Agreement. Thirdly, the European Union attaches great importance to the other high-level events in Katowice. We are looking forward to the high-level ministerial dialogue on climate finance and the stocktake on pre-2020 implementation and ambition to showcase progress and identify opportunities for action. We are contributing towards the developed countries’ collective goal of mobilising USD 100-billion per year by 2020 to address the needs of developing countries. In 2017, the Commission and the European Investment Bank contributed approximately EUR 5.5 billion of climate finance to developing countries. That is encouraging, but we must continue to catalyse and accelerate action from all economic actors to reach the objectives of the Paris Agreement. We should all offer our strong support to the Polish COP24 Presidency with a view to a successful outcome in Katowice.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank, first and foremost, Parliament for its strong support for biodiversity policy. Although less visible in the media, the global biodiversity crisis has social and economic implications known to be as serious as the climate crisis. Indeed, the two global challenges are intrinsically linked. This Commission has already done a lot to tackle the problem and the work to scale up efforts will continue right through to the end of our current mandate.  Let me mention, in particular, the Action Plan for nature, people and the economy, to accelerate implementation of the EU nature directives; the EU initiative to tackle the decline of pollinators; two guidance documents on integrating ecosystem services in decision-making and on EU-level green infrastructure, to be adopted soon; and ongoing work on a second update of the Union List of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern. I would also highlight the important work we are doing to engage the private sector in this issue under the EU Business @ Biodiversity Platform and through the Natural Capital Financing Facility, which has strong synergies with the concrete proposals adopted by this Commission under the Sustainable Finance Package. Building on these instruments, coupled with efforts to tackle climate change, including through transforming development aid policy and increased investments in Africa, should in future help to leverage more effectively the resources and commitments needed to address global biodiversity decline. We are also tackling the problem at international level through other means, namely our Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking and our work on Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade (FLEGT). Member States also have important responsibilities and the Commission will continue supporting their efforts whilst continuing to ensure compliance with EU nature legislation. For the period after 2020, the Commission has proposed an enhanced LIFE programme that will notably include a stronger focus on nature and biodiversity. Most importantly, given the crucial importance of sound agricultural policy to reverse biodiversity decline, as you know, the Commission has adopted a new legislative proposal on the common agricultural policy (CAP) post-2020, which includes higher climate and environmental ambitions. It will be of utmost importance that this House fully backs these ambitions. With regard to the post-2020 global biodiversity framework, the Commission concurs with the Council’s conclusions of 9 October that the framework should include targets that are, as far as possible, measurable and time-bound, an adequate monitoring framework and voluntary commitments from parties, citizens and the private sector, accompanied by a mechanism to review their implementation and to ensure accountability. This should be accompanied by an action agenda that mobilises non-state actors, communication campaigns and the political process at the highest levels. These elements should significantly strengthen global biodiversity policy.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, a warm welcome to the Council too! Biodiversity and climate protection go hand in hand. While the implementation of Paris will be discussed at COP 24 in Katowice, COP 14 is celebrating its 25th birthday in Egypt this year. We take this opportunity to reiterate and reinforce the importance of protecting our biodiversity worldwide. Together with colleagues from the other groups, we therefore believe it is essential to strengthen efforts and to draw up an ambitious strategic plan for the post-2020 period with a view to 2050. That is why, in our motion for a resolution, we call on the European Commission and the Member States to continue to take the lead in protecting biodiversity. To this end, it is important to step up efforts to achieve the 2020 targets, to introduce a stronger implementation mechanism similar to that in Paris and to ensure adequate funding. In the resolution, we deal with six points, two of which I would like to mention explicitly: our call for a robust international framework for the post-2020 period – we are in favour of performance indicators, which is also a key point for the effectiveness of the 2050 strategic plan – and, in particular, the highlighting of the positive contributions of forestry and agriculture to biodiversity. Only well-managed agriculture and forestry make a major contribution to the diversity of species, habitats and ecosystems.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it has been mentioned before that the world’s leading scientists warned us only two weeks ago that we dramatically have to step up our efforts worldwide and also in Europe. They also made very clear what the difference is between 1.5 and 2 degrees. Some will point out – rightly – that the coral reefs will disappear, but as a Social Democrat, I really want to outline what the effect will be on people and on our societies. We risk major humanitarian catastrophes and climate conflicts, triggering new waves of climate refugees, for instance, and we risk a rise in human suffering all over the world.  It is very important that we as Europe take up our responsibilities, and we need to step up our reduction targets for 2030, but, Commissioners – in the plural – we need also to ensure climate neutrality for 2050. That is why we as a group urge the Commission to come up with an updated 2050 strategy that is really Paris-proof.

text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am a representative of the region, which this year will host a climate conference in Katowice. But I also hope, Commissioner, that you will struggle to understand the scale of the challenges facing mining regions in the face of the European Union's climate policy. The aim of this year's climate conference will mainly be to develop mechanisms for implementing the Paris Agreement. Poland strongly supports this agreement and the amendment, which I will table on behalf of the EKR, remains in the spirit of this agreement. It clarifies that our aim is to strike a balance between emissions and removal capacity, as defined by the Paris Agreement. It also removes the objective adopted by the ENVI Committee, which the Commission has proposed, by talking about an immediate increase in the level of emission reductions to 55 %. We absolutely cannot agree with this objective. As for biodiversity, Poland is the best example of a well-run biodiversity.

text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I greet the Commissioners as much as I greet the Council and, of course, my dear colleagues. We have just heard about climate change and the mountain region. I want to go into the wet and talk about what climate change means for the oceans. The oceans are hugely important to us. Every second breath comes from the sea, where oxygen is produced, and less can be produced if climate change continues. Because it is also the case that CO2 can be bound by the seas. So here, too, the seas – healthy seas – have an important climate function. Now it is the case that, for example, the melting of the ice caps at the pole – the Greenland ice is also melting – just changes the water: it becomes less salty. As a result, it sinks less quickly to the ground, and there is therefore a changed exchange of fresh water. This in turn influences the Gulf Stream, which also makes our climate. It will change sooner or later, because the Gulf Stream has already slowed down and is also changing in shape, something that has been the case for almost millennia – not for millennia, but has been so for a long time: in Europe it could get colder, on the east coast of North America warmer. And of course, this also has an impact on the biodiversity that exists in the zones: fishing and much more. One more thing: we have just heard about the coral reefs. At 1.5° many coral reefs are already dying, at 2° they will die. And now you can say: Well, then you can not see such beautiful colorful fish while diving. But that is not the point. The point is really that the coral reefs are a haven for many species that live and grow up in the sea, and at the same time a bulwark against natural disasters such as tsunamis or other. They therefore also have a protective function for the respective continents. The last thing: When sea levels rise, islands will disappear. You can say: Well, a few islands less. But, of course, as Mrs Van Brempt has already mentioned, there will then be climate refugees, and that will therefore have a major impact on this too. The sea level rises very differently depending on where you are on the globe. So the ocean is very important for people, and that is why we should make sure that we get to grips with climate change.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think that it is very good that we are discussing climate and biodiversity at the same time, because we all know that we have global pledges on the table, but Europe is not on track in meeting those pledges. That should be discussed. I will focus first on climate because I have only 45 seconds left, and maybe just to start with the Presidency. To be very honest, your Presidency conclusions on COP24 in Katowice are just a repetition of what we already promised in the Paris agreement: that we are going to look at our pledges on the table, that was the idea of the Paris agreement. The Council should take a step further and not just reiterate what we already promised in 2015. That brings me to the Commission and a very plain question: I know that you have said that in your long-term strategy, Mr Cañete, you said that we are going to look at a zero-carbon for 2050 scenario. However, what does that mean for 2030? Are you also going to make sure that that scenario will include, as the scientists ask for, that Europe will move to -55% to -60% by 2030?

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, last month I attended the Global Climate Action Summit in San Francisco and I was heartened by how some of the federal states are still committing to Paris targets, despite persistent climate change denial from the Trump administration. The EU needs this same determination at COP24, especially now that there is a leadership vacuum to fill following the US withdrawal from Paris. Climate action isn’t easy. It requires governments to make radical changes to their economies. My country, Ireland, especially must ensure that all of its policy areas are coherent with reaching our climate targets. On a global, EU and national scale, we are way off track. Parliament’s resolution on COP24 stresses that the current nationally determined contributions would only curb global warming to 3.2°, nowhere close to the 2° commitment in Paris. On top of that, the UN climate body’s recent report projected the disastrous effects of even 2° and how it is crucial to curb warming at 1.5° to prevent massive human and ecological losses. The EU has no other choice but to rise to the challenge of COP24 and not bow to the lobbyists.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Commissioners, as rapporteur of the European Parliament for COP 21, co-editor for COP 23 and member of Parliament's delegation to COP 24 in Poland, I believe that universal access to sustainable energy in developing countries must be one of the priorities of this COP 24. Safe and predictable access to energy is the challenge of the 21st century, especially for the African continent, which will have 4.5 billion people by the end of this century compared to 1.3 billion today, or nearly 40% of the world's population. Today, two-thirds of Africa's population does not have access to electricity. As a result, these 860 million people have very difficult access to education, health, the labour market and all sectors of life that require electricity. Commissioner, at the second edition of the 'One Planet Summit' organised by French President Emmanuel Macron on 26 September in New York, the European Commission has pledged to invest 44 billion euros in clean energy projects in Africa. Can you tell us more tonight?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Yes, climate change and biodiversity loss, these are two global crises that are closely intertwined. The way in which humanity will now address it will determine health, well-being, prosperity for future generations. Investing in nature and biodiversity must be at the heart of a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe. On top of the overwhelming intrinsic value of nature, biodiversity offers unaffordable socio-economic benefits. It is more than two and a half years since we approved my report on biodiversity here. Although the Commission has taken a number of initiatives – and the Commissioner has referred to them – there is still no structural progress. Without additional efforts, we will miss the 2020 targets. Moreover, the Commission remains worryingly silent about a post-2020 strategy. On climate policy, however, the co-legislators have only just agreed on an ambitious legislative framework by 2030. And ambition is needed, but we also like to link that to realism. Of course, everything can always be improved, but calling these agreements that have just been made inadequate is neither serious nor realistic.

text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is time to ban fossil fuels and invest in climate change in by far the most vulnerable regions and people. One is that these exaggerated commitments have adverse economic and social consequences that Member States must bear. On the other, the EU is responsible for 10% of total CO2 emissions. A global problem cannot be solved locally, only through worldwide cooperation. The most important area is climate diplomacy. We need to get the United States back to the Paris agreement. The small step forward is that now President Trump feels that there is climate change, and it is not just an attempt by the Chinese to scam.

text: – Mr President, Commissioners, the preparation for the conclusion of COP24 to be held in December is a challenge for both the Union and the other actors, the more than 180 parties which have already ratified the Paris Agreement, achieved during COP21. After the previous COP23 in Bonn and the Tanaloa Dialogue, we must take into account that COP24 in Katowice will probably be the first flying goal in Paris two years after its entry into force. Two years that, according to the World Meteorological Organization, have been the warmest years ever recorded. And not only that: this summer, the Mediterranean has recorded weather episodes of tropical characteristics with strong storms and winds that have hit the Levantine coast of Spain; episodes that coincide with the records of the harshest drought in central Europe with serious effects on agriculture.  This is climate change. It is not, as we heard on the street, that this year time has gone mad. Climate change is here and it is our task to put and implement the measures and objectives to reach the limit of one and a half degree of global temperature rise. And it is our task also to take steps so that when we are impacted by these extreme phenomena, we are alert and in the most attenuated way possible. And it is also the task of the European Union to continue to lead the world with ambition and realism in this struggle.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Mr President, there is, of course, a link between the climate issue and the issue of biodiversity, but I will focus on the issue of biodiversity, since that is my subject. We will say it very quietly: we wonder if these COPs (Conferences of the Parties) serve any purpose. Of course, we may be tempted to say, ''Ultimately, since we are not achieving the objectives, we have to push them back.'' The opposite reasoning must be held. We must live up to the objectives of COP14, and for that we must ask ourselves why we are not able to make what we proclaim a reality today. The reason may be simple: we do not give ourselves the means to do so.  Perhaps there is a rule to follow, the first is that indicators are needed. Indicators to know exactly where we stand, in particular, in the conduct and search of our objectives. This is essential: if we do not have tools, we cannot know why we succeed or why we fail. The second point , and I stress this, is that we will soon realize that it is not possible today to preserve biodiversity if we do not challenge one of the fundamental rules that we have set ourselves, unfortunately, which is the pursuit of profit at all costs. It is impossible to have an approach where the only values are money and profit and at the same time protect biodiversity. It is absolutely impossible and we will have to understand it.

I found it very encouraging in Bonn last year that many representatives of the United States – from the economy, from the regions, from the states – said: we are sticking with this process, and we also see great opportunities for jobs and economic growth.  However, I am very difficult with this debate. We need to increase our targets now, and dramatically. I spoke to many representatives of third countries in Bonn, and some of them did not understand my question at all. We all know that the current commitments are not enough; we must step up our efforts. We end up at about 3° if everyone supports their commitments from Paris, and that is a long way off alone by 2 °. That is why I do not believe that it is effective for us to decide now, as provided for in the resolution, that we should decide on 55% in the EU and not see what is happening in the rest of the world at all. I support our Commissioner, Miguel Arias Caete. We can raise the European climate target only by implementing the legislation that we have already adopted, but not to 55, but less. More importantly, we start an international process with China and others, that we are not the only ones raising the goals.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for 15-year-old Greta Thunberg from Sweden stood in front of the Swedish Parliament and went on a school strike for 15 days. As a parent, Of course, I cannot call on all schoolchildren to do the same, but it was a courageous act to mark against all politicians in parliaments that they are not doing enough and that she – as young as 15 – sees what the world needs. I would therefore like to say to all those citizens who, like Mrs Greta, are wondering what we are doing in these houses, that there are allies who want to fight for the Paris Agreement not only to become fine words, but also to be applied in laws and in our future. My message is: Don't give up! The UN Panel on Climate Change stated last week that there is a great risk that we will not reach the Paris Agreement. We need to increase the work considerably if we are to reach the target of 1.5 degrees. The clock cannot be turned back. We need to do much more. I will support 55% by 2030 and I expect all colleagues to support it, so that we have a good message for the climate conference in December.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, it came as no surprise to us that the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) told us that the measures already promised and the measures taken are not enough to prevent global warming by more than one and a half degrees.  We Social Democrats have worked to ensure that the EU's practical measures are in line with rhetoric. An agreement has already been reached with the Council on the ITRE Committee's renewable energy, energy efficiency and overall energy efficiency directives. The direction is right, but the pace is inadequate. In the past, Commissioner Cañete has estimated that the measures will lead to a 45% reduction in emissions in 2030. We need more, more quickly, as he said just now.  I support the tightening up of the EU's objectives. We also need a firm commitment from the Member States. I look forward to a slewed, important, Commission long-term emission reduction strategy before Katowice. We also need decisions to tighten up emissions trading. We need clean energy, technology and sustainable material solutions. Political leadership is needed around the world for a clear direction in the world and for giving consumers opportunities, and for the sake of children we need responsibility for a sustainable planet in the future.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This year's climate conference in Poland is a test for the world community. The report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change speaks volumes. We are too late, we are doing too little and efforts need to be improved. Above all, of course, we need the rule book with the transparency of the data, so that we also know what everyone is doing and cannot be deceived here, and we can also measure real progress. It is also a test for Europe. It is a climate conference again on our continent, in the European Union, and we should lead by example. I agree with all those who say here that we must offer the world community a greater ambition of the European Union. And we can do that because of the legislation that is behind us. I hope that the Council of Environment Ministers and other decision-makers will be able to decide, by Katowice, to increase our 40% reduction target. It is right to say that Europe cannot protect the climate alone; we need others in the world. In the future, we may also have to consider measures at our borders, because then we will have the costs for our companies, but others will not have the costs for their companies. We will have to talk again about border levies in favour of climate protection. But we also need the long-term forward, the long-term plan for 2050. I hope that this will be a future plan for the EU. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much to Mr Leinen. He spoke of the others in the world who should help us to improve the climate accordingly. I have now read in the newspaper that Elon Musk has de facto given up the chairmanship of Tesla and Mr Murdoch Jr. took over this job. We know that Murdoch has massively driven Brexit in the UK. Is it probable that the diesel exit and the bashing of diesel will now also be carried out for these political reasons?

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Rübig, I would like to thank Mr Rübig for his work on this The production of electric cars and the diesel bashing by Mr Murdoch – that is a real balancing act. In fact, you are addressing an issue that we are all aware of, that we need new forms of propulsion, that we are concerned that they are produced more outside the EU than within the EU – Tesla in the US and the Chinese there in their country. I believe that the car industry must understand that the clock will run out for them if it does not go into modernisation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, I can't get enough of saying that the fight against climate change has to have a global priority. But once again, we are going to a COP to observe that the compromise ratified in the Paris Agreement is not being fulfilled, and the reality, ladies and gentlemen, is that as we walk here to discuss, week in, week out, what targets, whether mandatory or voluntary, what reductions, what ambitions and what collective and individual commitment we will have to take so that the impacts of the changes are mitigated in my country, the effects are more than visible, with forest fires that destroy precious resources and kill people. Ladies and gentlemen, this is the time to act and, to do so, there needs to be a clear compromise on the part of the Member States, and this has to happen, as has already been said before Katowice, under penalty of going to the COP in vain.  The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has already shown that we should aim at a limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius and not 2, so that the impacts to which we will be subject are less severe. To that do so, I believe that Europe must speak with one voice in the various international forums. We must lead by example and set aside national interests so that we can demand everyone at the negotiating table to give this commitment to environmental protection the urgency it needs. Thank you very much.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, the fight against climate change is an obligation and it is more, if possible, an obligation when we constantly observe droughts, fires, floods , such as those that have just happened in my country, Spain. Therefore, we have to be ambitious. We need to show, like the European Union, leadership, capacity for ambition and determination. For this we must also lead by example, and it would be good if the European Union set a more ambitious emission reduction target by 2030. It is possible — after what we have done with the Energy Efficiency Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive — to go to at least a 45% emission reduction target. It is therefore necessary that at this Climate Summit we show this determination and ambition to take steps and for the European Union, once the United States has abandoned us, to keep that firm and determined pulse to combat climate change.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Union is trying to live up to the Paris commitments, but it has entrusted this process to the carbon trading scheme, the ETS, which relies on market forces and is therefore not effective. At the same time, there is a lot of speculation. The Greek PPC is obliged every year to pay 400 million euros for ets and now this burden will reach 600 million euros, at a time when there is precision in the current, there is energy poverty and, at the same time, expensive heating oil. However, Bulgaria and Poland are excluded from the market for gaseous pollutant allowances. The question is why should this exception not be granted to the Greek PPC, to have the same treatment as the Bulgarian PPC, in order to be able to respond to a difficult phase for the Greek economy and Greek society.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, there are questions which are not, but should be included in, the questions that frame this debate. With regard to the Climate Change Conference, COP 24, this is one more that goes without questioning the perversity and ineffectiveness of market instruments such as carbon trading.  Environmental objectives succumb to the business, even those that are done with the purchase and sale of pollution rights. With regard to the conference on biological diversity, COP 14, it is curious that there is talk of new financial instruments for biodiversity, with nothing being said about the lack, to date, for more than twenty-five years, of a Community instrument dedicated to financing the management and conservation of natura 2000. On the contrary, there is a clear unaccountability of the European Union in this area, a failure that neither the CAP nor the LIFE programme fills. They prefer, it is true, to channel resources into the arms industry and to the ongoing militaristic escalation. Escusam is to paint the face green.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. In recent years, it has become clear that we need to make much more effort than ever before to stop the harmful effects of climate change. It also shows that states can only have a limited impact by changing the regulatory environment. In the future, it will not be enough if we only seek to reduce emissions from road transport, and progress must also be made in agriculture, industry, energy, air and water transport. We need to change the entire functioning of our society to a new reality. The developed world can set a good example on this issue, but developing states also need a change of model. If there is a global challenge today that requires the joint effort and sacrifice of all of us, then climate change is definitely one. Because sacrifice will be absolutely necessary, the question is how big this sacrifice will be and when we accept that it is inevitable.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protection of biodiversity and the fight against climate change are among the priorities of European environmental policies. Most of the 2020 targets, however, will not be met, and the financial mobilisation for the climate, of one hundred billion dollars per year by 2020, is also proceeding very slowly. Support should be provided for the establishment of new financing instruments for biodiversity and enhanced accountability instruments should be proposed, in particular for national biodiversity strategies and action plans, in order to improve governance and facilitate the implementation of the post-2020 objectives. For climate change, on the other hand, it is necessary to strengthen the European Union's relations with local and regional authorities, to strengthen cooperation between cities, to strengthen sustainable development models and emission reduction plans in key sectors, such as energy, industry, technology, agriculture and transport, for example with twinning programmes, the international urban cooperation programme, support for platforms such as the 'Covenant of Mayors' and by building new forums for the exchange of best practices.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: "I'm in favour of setting the bar high, but in sport. As far as climate is concerned, in terms of ecology, I would have preferred this bar to be set above all wisely, precisely and taking into account the start-up of individual economic operators or simply the state. I would add – le my doubt – I am in favour of reducing these negative effects of industrial activity, economic activity on the climate. On the other hand, I believe that the experience from this perspective until 2020 is unfortunately negative, and I believe that it would be necessary to make the tasks much more flexible and adaptable to specific objectives and, above all, to avoid, above all, to create a situation in which everyone is convinced that these tasks have been arranged primarily in order to punish someone.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the international summits we are discussing here cannot be just a major global and media event. Limiting global warming in the terms set out in the Paris Agreement can mean the difference between the life and death of people and ecosystems and is also crucial for the preservation of biodiversity. It is therefore necessary to set more ambitious targets and channel more funding to biodiversity conservation. It is no longer enough to communicate with indicators and graphs, Commissioner, it is the survival of humanity, as we know it, that is at stake. As shadow rapporteur of the energy governance regulation, which will be voted on in the next plenary here in Strasbourg, I have tried to ensure that the Energy Union's 2030 climate targets will be achieved through coherent and flexible policies. You have to act. If selfish and anthropocentric competition for resources destroys the foundations of natural balances, we ourselves are the ones who destroy ourselves and cannot allow it.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the EU has a responsibility to all living things to lead efforts towards ambitious action against climate change. As climate sceptics, led by Donald Trump, imperil biodiversity it is crucial that we Europeans lead the way. Women and young people must play a central part in our climate change strategy. In fact, tackling climate change is an opportunity to foster positive change in broader areas of society. Women play a particularly significant role in crucial sectors in rural areas, and they must be at the forefront of our work. Our climate policies must also go hand in hand with our human rights policies, for example we must stand up for indigenous people against land grabs and deforestation, particularly in the Amazon, which is the lungs of the world. Climate change challenges the ways our societies have developed with the growing phenomenon of climate refugees fleeing unsustainable lives and we must therefore radically reshape the way we are living now, for the sake of future generations.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for the good debate and useful suggestions. Halting biodiversity loss, not only on land but also in our oceans, must become more than just a goal. I agree with those of you who said that to really make it happen, we need to shift up a gear by building on financial instruments and optimising policies such as development aid to put in place a solid process for voluntary commitments that can attract adequate resources, together with clear, quantifiable global targets. Ongoing scientific work will help us better understand and quantify the biological and economic implications of living within planetary boundaries. This should put us in a better position to translate policy objectives into operational and effective measures. Of course, we will also need to mobilise adequate resources to achieve our goals. This is an investment that is necessary and urgent, considering that the cost of inaction is increasing exponentially. Consequential social and economic costs are not simply an ambiguous concept. We know for a fact that biodiversity loss has direct links to human displacement, migration and global security concerns linked to food and water. The conservation and restoration of biodiversity can therefore be a powerful antidote to these challenges. We have started our preparatory work with the evaluation of the EU biodiversity strategy to 2020, including plans for stakeholder consultation. This will contribute to the discussions on the post-2020 Global Framework. We need to rise up to this opportunity and take a lead in encouraging global partners to act with us. I am confident that with your support and the support of EU citizens, we can make the COP 15 in Beijing in 2020 a game changer. On the 2018 UN Climate Change Conference, strong and united European Union messaging will be instrumental to continue to deliver on our leadership during COP 24 in Katowice and beyond. The European Commission and the Council, under the leadership of the Austrian Presidency, will contribute to the conclusion of the negotiations on the Paris work programme, so as to enable the Paris agreement to be fully implemented and global progress on curbing emissions to be tracked transparently and regularly. After Katowice, our work must continue both domestically and internationally. With our domestic experience and external policy instruments and dialogues, we are in a position to help our partners to advance their transition to a low-carbon, climate-resilient economy. We should also assume a leadership position in prompting our partners to develop their long-term strategies if possible already ahead of the climate summit, which is to be convened by UN Secretary General Guterres in September 2019, or in any case for 2020 as foreseen under the Paris agreement. I would like to take you for the opportunity of having this debate. The Commission looks forward to continuing our dialogue in the future.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for their cooperation. I am very much encouraged by our joint debate on COP14 and COP24 today. As on previous occasions, your support on outreach efforts to our international partners is very much appreciated. The IPCC report shows that, collectively, the parties’ nationally determined contributions fall short of what is required to achieve the long—term mitigation goal. All countries must contribute to accelerated short-term action and enhanced longer term ambition. As expressed by the Council, the EU is ready to communicate or update its nationally determined contribution by 2020, taking into account the collective further efforts needed and the actions undertaken by all parties to meet the objectives of the Paris agreement. In the context of COP14, we welcome the initiative of Egypt to host a high—level segment in November 2018, just before COP14, to discuss mainstreaming biodiversity into energy and mining, infrastructure, manufacturing, processing and the health sectors. The Council also stresses the importance of convening a high—level biodiversity summit, at the level of heads of state and government in 2020, to strengthen the political visibility of biodiversity and its vital contribution to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. We very much appreciate the support of the European Parliament and its important contributions to our work in the run-up to COP14 and COP24. I very much look forward to continuing this exchange and working closely together in the run-up to the conferences in Katowice and Sharm El Sheikh in order to achieve the best possible outcome.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5)) will be announced later. The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – I wish to welcome the work of the ENVI rapporteurs on the resolution on the 2018 UN Climate Change Conference in Poland, which will focus on the full implementation of the Paris Agreement. Unfortunately, we are witnessing a present with more and more extreme weather events and temperature records around the world, which are deeply worrying and demand for immediate global action. Irreversible impacts could be still avoided if all states which ratified the Paris Agreement prove their responsibility and do their utmost through well-defined individual contributions. In this context, I would like to stress the importance for third-country beneficiaries of the Green Fund to be effectively and continuously assisted and monitored by relevant EU bodies in order to ensure their progress and compliance. I strongly believe that setting binding climate-related targets for each beneficiary is crucial in order to assure that the Fund brings the desired outcomes and maximises European taxpayers’ confidence in this mechanism’s capability to deliver. Europe is, and needs to be, in the forefront of the world combat against climate change.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. "The problems caused by climate change are not far in the future, but its effects are already visible and felt. Greenhouse gases reached record levels last year, temperatures are above average, Arctic ice is melting at a record rate and extreme weather phenomena are becoming more common. The earth has already warmed by one degree compared to pre-industrial times. Further warm-up threatens not only humans, but also many species of plants and animals. A report published by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in October illustrates the huge difference between 1.5 and 2.0 degrees Celsius of warming. In order to halt global warming to one and a half degrees, ambitious measures are needed, such as investment in new technologies and significant tightening of emission reductions. Sticking to the current emission commitments would mean that the earth would warm by 3°C by the end of the century, with catastrophic consequences. I hope that at the Katowice meeting, which is to decide on the practical implementation of the Paris Agreement on climate change, all parties will understand the seriousness of the situation. The scientific world has spoken, and now it's time for action. Climate change is a challenge of the size that requires cooperation between all countries and citizens and the blowing together.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – I welcome the proposed legislation, as it tightens the maximum available limit for certain environmental contaminants, such as lead and other harmful bacteria, while introducing new ceilings for certain hormonal disruptors.  Member States should take measures to ensure universal access to clean water in the EU. They should also actually improve access to drinking water in public places, for example by setting up drinking areas where it is reasonable and feasible. In restaurants and restaurants, free or affordable use of tap water should be encouraged. We are already doing all this in my Member State, which I am very proud of.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Daniele Viotti and Paul Rübig, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the General budget of the European Union for the financial year 2019 – all sections  (11737/2018 – C8—0410/2018 – 2018/2046(BUD)) (A8—0313/2018).

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this debate that we can have today on the draft budget that we will be voting on Wednesday in this House. I think I can say, representing the sentiments of my fellow Members who worked with me in the Committee on Budgets – which I would like to thank, of course, also and above all the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with me – I think I can represent everyone's feeling by saying that we have presented a budget proposal that is both ambitious but also sustainable.  Sustainable because we are not asking the Member States for additional efforts compared to those they already make in supporting the financial framework and supporting the budget of our European Union, and because we are trying to use all the resources at our disposal, we want to use all the resources at our disposal to return them to the citizens of Europe. Ambitious because we are trying to respond to all European citizens with the proposals we want to make, as well as to businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises that are suffering, and above all to the most innovative companies; we try to give important answers to our universities, to our local administrations (the regions and municipalities), and we try to give answers to our research institutions. Just as we are trying – through the budget that we have written and will vote on, I think and hope with a large majority on Wednesday – to respond to the great challenges that await us and that await our continent: growth, solidarity between states but also solidarity with citizens, as well as the great issue of migration, which seems to no longer abandon the debate of our countries and the debate of european citizens. On migration, we are trying not to give the first answers, You see, Mr President, but let us try to deal with the problems as they need to be dealt with, that is, point by point and sector by sector, by trying to give overall answers or, as we say in this House, a holistic response. Let us try to give an answer that includes all the sectors of these phenomena because, above all, we will try to give answers that are supportive responses but that are also preventive actions. That is why we have also focused a great deal on preventive actions. We have also focused a great deal – and my fellow Members know this – on the subject of eradication, that is, trying to remove the reasons for migration and then try to remove, defeat, fight poverty, try to defeat drought, try to defeat the reasons why there are migrations. And then our biggest challenge, Mr President: the younger generation. A great commitment in our budget is on the younger generations, in particular on the Erasmus project, which is not only a symbolic project of our Europe but must become, from next year as well as in the years to come, a project to which all young people and young people on our continent can join. And then there is the Youth Guarantee: because the greatest concern of all of us can only be unemployment, the enormous youth unemployment that runs through our country. I am not naïve, of course, Mr President, I know that this is a first step, I know that a first step is now beginning, and I think that the others should take them with the Commission that accompanies us, and I thank Commissioner Oettinger for that, and with the Council, I thank you for the very close attention that Mr Loger is putting into the formation of this budget. The question we must ask ourselves, Minister, that we must all ask ourselves in the coming weeks and months, before closing the budget, is that Europe and what image of Europe we want to give back to the citizens of Europe before the next elections: whether a Europe that still looks at the 'zero commas', whether a Europe that is only attentive to measures with neighbouring percentages, etc., or whether a Europe that looks to the great challenges and the future. These are the questions that we will have to answer and if we answer together, in my opinion, we will find the right answer to give to the citizens, returning to the values, traditions and bets that we face.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Federal Minister Löger, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for her excellent work. We have an important year ahead of us. 2019 will be the first year in which we have to fix the multiannual financial framework, the new financial framework. That is why it is crucial that the priorities that Mr Viotti has just mentioned here should be taken into account in the negotiations. We will only be voting this week on what the European Parliament's position is, but the political groups have already discussed many details and we are already quite agreed that we want to set some priorities for next year, such as the design of Horizon 2020, the COSME programme, youth, migration, research, connecting Europe facility, the issue of security – so there are many points. , where I believe that it also makes sense to reach an agreement with the Council, because, of course, the European added value for next year – we will have elections next year – can also be brought to the citizens' understanding accordingly. Finally, it is also a question of showing what it costs us – namely the citizens and the taxpayers – if Europe does not do it. The cost of non-Europe is a very important issue, which we should also communicate more widely in public, because it is also a question of showing in subsidiarity at what level which decisions should be taken. These decisions are very important for our future, bearing in mind that the defence of democracy also has a value – unity in diversity – and that is why the Erasmus programme should also be designed for groups working to defend democracy in Europe. But that brings me to my specific budget, which are the other sections, as it is so beautifully called. It is the ten institutions that, in addition to the Commission, shape Europe and shape Europe. Perhaps I will start with the European Parliament. This is the House that represents the citizens of Europe, and it is important for us that we also show to the governments that we have common objectives. I am actually very happy that the European Parliament has decided to keep heading V below 20% again today, which is actually our red line. In fact, for fifteen years now, we have had the lowest share of heading V that has ever existed, namely 18.53 %. This is the lowest figure in the last fifteen years. I believe that Parliament is already showing here that we are also prepared to make savings. We have also chosen to have lump sums for Members and for officials and our staff in various areas. We can also save ourselves enormous costs from the flat-rate costs, which have now been confirmed by the European Court of Justice, because, of course, a fact-check would require a great many new posts and therefore the flat-rate allowance is actually the right approach for us, including in the personal responsibility of Members towards the public. We have a number of Members in the House who are calling for more and more transparency in this area. I can only encourage colleagues to be transparent, but put your bills on the Internet for all lump sums. You have the opportunity to present this on your own homepage accordingly. I have taken a closer look at this this summer: there is not a single Member in the House who publishes supporting documents, and I think that is also right, because, of course, the flat rate justifies the cost of having it further in the future. I am also in favour of a closer look at the voluntary pension fund. I am also calling for a study by the Court of Auditors. I believe that a solution must be found that respects the Members' Statute. That is why it is also a question of giving the European Court of Justice and the External Action Service additional resources accordingly. There are new challenges here. Finally, it is a question of the European Parliament also having fulfilled the 5% reduction in posts. This is now reflected in the 2019 budget accordingly. I can also say that, of course, the election year has given us slightly increased costs. All in all, however, I am very satisfied with the way in which the current proposals are being made by the Council, the Commission and, of course, the European Parliament.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger and ladies, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for her excellent work. It is an honour for me to be here today to follow Parliament's debate on the 2019 budget.  I myself had the opportunity, a month ago, to comment on the Commission and the Council's proposal in the form of the Council, in relation to the Commission's proposal, and I concluded at the time that we share a common basis on the essential points of our proposals – the priorities that we want to set together for this Europe. We have in the priorities together a growing, innovative and competitive economy, which we are making a priority of, and at the same time we want to give young people in Europe in particular a new opportunity so that they can reach their full potential.  In their proposal i presented, the Member States are prepared to finance a substantial increase in the budget compared to previous years in order to meet these challenges. The Council itself proposes that the current budget should be increased by more than 2%, which is a much higher basis than the national budgets of many countries. As Finance Minister, I am confronted every day– including in my country – with the fact that, of course, there must also be awareness that state budgets are financed by taxpayers and that we also have a responsibility in the decisions that we take here in this context. Ladies and gentlemen! I would also like us to take note of the fact that, particularly in the Council proposal, the issue of science occupies a very, very important place and that we also see it as an opportunity to promote social peace and job security in Europe. We also want to ensure that the people of Europe find a faster way – both at the level of the Internet, but also in traditional transport routes. And we also want to ensure that migration, as one of Europe's greatest challenges, has appropriate support.  To put it more specifically, we have therefore provided in our proposal for a 10% increase for the Erasmus programme, a significant increase in the horizon 2020 area, 30% more also for data networks and transport networks, and a significant increase in funding for migration. However, it must also be clear to us that we can only set these priorities if we also deal carefully with the other areas of Europe's financial resources. I can only repeat that this 2019 budget must also be designed efficiently, modernly and appropriately in order to create this space for priorities. We also want to provide sufficient margins to deal with unforeseen situations. We are all realising that not only Brexit within Europe, but also of global frameworks, pose major challenges, and we should also take responsibility for the citizens of Europe in this context to include the financial resources for this.  I believe that it is particularly important, in connection with the discussion of this budget, to respect the decisions taken in the past. We have a multiannual financial framework, we have the mid-term review, but we have also made financial arrangements in connection with legislative proposals. I also appeal to you in this context to respect these requirements. I myself am sure that we can keep the timetable that we have set ourselves, which was also agreed between our institutions for the budget negotiations. In doing so, we also want to ensure that we can reach an agreement within the deadlines set in the Treaty. I look forward to the further talks and negotiations that we will have together in the coming weeks.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Minister Löger, honourable Members, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to express my respect to the rapporteurs, Mr Viotti and Mr Rübig, for excellent preparatory work here in this House for a position that you are discussing and deciding on this week. The Council, Parliament and the Commission – we are in agreement on the priorities that we want to achieve, want to improve, and strengthen with budgetary resources. It is about economic strength and growth, it is about jobs and jobs, especially for young people, it is about meaningful projects in the field of migration, it is about external and internal security. I would also like to thank you, Minister Löger, for showing through your presence that it is a matter for you to take part in these negotiations in 2019 and, with all due respect to your officials, to be responsible for themselves. Thank you for the hours you are here and are ready to spend the next few weeks with us actively in the interests of an orderly adoption. There is still a difference in the need for funding for the programmes that we are currently focusing on. The allocation of funds for the priorities must therefore be given expert and thorough advice in the coming weeks. However, I welcome the goodwill and willingness to reach agreement, for cooperation, which has so far been shown by all the budgetary authorities. The timetable for mid-November is clear, and I see a good chance of reaching an agreement in this period, which we have jointly defined by the sequence of meetings. What are the most important questions for consultation? Firstly, competitiveness. Parliament is proposing an increase that goes beyond the Commission's draft when it comes to programmes for SMEs, young people, climate protection and competitiveness. The Council wants to increase programmes such as Horizon 2020 or Connecting Europe, if compared to 2018, if the Commission's proposal is taken, to cut back somewhat. We will be able to provide further advice in the coming weeks along projects for which funding is requested and through ongoing and new research projects. I believe that research and innovation, that the promotion of SMEs are crucial for European competitiveness, should be indisputable in this House and between all three institutions. In particular, we see programmes with a high European added value at Connecting Europe and Horizon 2020, where it makes sense to bring funds to the European level and then invest together. That is why we are convinced that the Council's cuts of EUR 800 million are not really comprehensible and are contrary to these jointly stated priorities. We must all be clear: those who declare priorities must also be prepared to say where they do not prioritise, where cuts are also accepted. The employment situation for young people in Europe has improved. This affects most regions, but not all regions. That is why the programmes that we are now continuing to finance are about accuracy and the question: what can actually be implemented by the Member States and the local administrative authorities? The appropriation only makes sense if it is ambitious but also realistic. That is why, for both the Youth Work Initiative and the Social Fund, we will be listing in the coming weeks exactly what size of implementation we consider to be realistic. In the case of Erasmus+, agreement should be easy. It makes sense to increase this and serves to get young people to get to know Europe and therefore also to support Europe on the path of their future lives. The third priority is external action and migration. In September, the Commission presented a new migration package with which we intend to take the first steps towards strengthening Frontex, the Border and Coast Guard. We think it is very important that This is supported by Parliament. The Facility for Refugees in Turkey.
