In retrospect, I would like to tell you that, despite an EU-unfriendly policy by the government in Ankara, the funds arrive one-to-one where temporary refugees are housed. We are funding human dignity for 1.2 million refugees. The first instalment has been allocated and used up. That is why our concern as the Commission is on the question of who finances what, above all, one thing: we cannot allow ourselves to delay, we should keep our word, we need another EUR 3 billion for the second tranche, so that this funding of human dignity for the number of refugees continues without interruption, for example by employing 8 000 teachers to ensure that young people are able to do so. - 300 000 in number - education, basic education remains possible. We should not be blunt about the issue with Ankara, keep our word in the interests of the people who are important to all of us. With the pre-accession aid to Turkey, for which my colleague Mr Hahn is in charge and where, in addition to the cuts proposed by the Commission, both the Council and Parliament propose further cuts, my idea is as follows: we should only invest, but just as much, as is still possible in projects for democracy, for the rule of law, for civil society, for the order of values, for NGOs. This means that the more and the sooner we have projects and contacts that go in the right direction – providing money for this makes sense. We do not need more than that. We sent you a letter of amendment a few days ago. This is about the usual adjustment of agricultural expenditure in the autumn, environmental and climate objectives, and smaller changes which are more technical. Then, with our letter of amendment, we also translated recently adopted legislative proposals into figures. The new programme for industrial development in the defence sector, the European Solidarity Corps, the programme to support structural reforms and also three new Commission proposals: an increase of 750 posts next year from Frontex, the strengthening of the European Agency for Asylum and ten posts for the work of our parties and foundations are included in these amendments. I look forward to good consultation. We will do everything we can to ensure that the time frame is maintained.

name: Kati PIRI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, I am replacing here today my colleague Brando Benifei who is the AFET rapporteur on the 2019 budget. I would also like to express my gratitude to budget rapporteur Daniele Viotti. However, there is one negative element which will have far-reaching consequences for candidate country Turkey, as has already been mentioned by the Commissioner. We all agree that political developments in Turkey are not doing well and, therefore, the Commission’s decision to cut 40% of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA II) envelope is extreme but justifiable. However, on top of this and in contradiction with the vote in the Foreign Affairs Committee, the Committee on Budgets has decided to cut another EUR 147 million, this means that the very much-needed financial assistance for civil society and Syrian refugees in Turkey can no longer sufficiently be financed. I would, therefore, like to urge my colleagues to alter this budget line in such a way that the EU can continue its help for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey and if there is no modification in the budget, we will hurt those in Turkey who need us most.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I support the Committee on Development's call for official development assistance to finally be increased to 0.7% of gross national income by 2030. This applies both to the Member States and to the EU. The EU pledges that 0.2% of gross national income should be spent on the least developed countries as a whole. The Committee on Development also called for the first time in this year's decision that the costs of receiving refugees in donor countries should not be included in the calculation of official development assistance as before.  Only if the funding target of 0.7% is met by the EU in the coming years, as in many Member States, will the 2030 Agenda with the SDGs have any chance at all. Unfortunately, the EU has so far lacked the will to use a recognisable strategic budgetary prioritisation to implement the objectives of the Sustainable Development Agenda in development cooperation.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Madam President, the Commissioner addressed Turkey and I am very glad that he did. It was also addressed by the shadow rapporteur from the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET). I am just going to focus on one budget item and that is the pre-accession funding for Turkey. A report has come out which says that the reality is that the funds spent under the IPA I objectives have barely addressed the independence and impartiality of justice, the fight against high-level corruption, and press freedom. As a matter of fact, there are more journalists in prison in Turkey than there are in Iran. These are quotes from the EU’s own Court of Auditors. For the record, Turkey is scheduled to receive pre-accession funding of EUR 1 940 billion 2018—2020. You always hear ‘European values’ here and this is simply an outrage. I urge colleagues to vote against this tomorrow. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur, question on the 'blue card' procedure. I would like to express my sincere thanks for this opinion, because international trade naturally plays an important role. I have noticed that the preparatory action that we in Parliament wanted, namely the strengthening of the WTO towards administration, because we have massive complaints that the judges will resign there, and – although America put a new case on the table a few days ago – no judges - no reappointment. Do you think it would be important to give more support to the WTO here, including from the European Union, including in the financial field?

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card answer. – I’m always charmed by Mr Rübig and especially on this occasion, and so I will just give a very short answer. I very much agree with you, and the WTO needs to be supported.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The 2019 budget shows how new challenges and institutions have come to the EU budget that need to be financed, such as the European Solidarity Corps, a Union-wide civil protection capacity reserve and others – Commissioner Oettinger mentioned them – while continuing existing efforts. With the financial year 2019, the current multiannual financial framework is entering its final sprint. It is true that the programmes in shared management, in particular, are still laggmy in their implementation. But a long-held wish of the Committee on Budgetary Control is finally becoming a reality: the European Public Prosecutor's Office is being set up. The recent murders of investigative journalists, who also dealt with the misuse of European funds, show how necessary this institution is. However, the budget and staffing levels envisaged are far too small for this authority to be able to start working. The States which have not yet joined the European Public Prosecutor's Office should also finally do so.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Madam President, let me share with you just three points from the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) to the budget. First of all, as we know, Member States are not very keen to have a large budget. This is the reality and, as a consequence, we must aim even more to use money in a highly efficient way in areas where it is required by EU citizens or where it creates high value-added. Second, ISAs are very important for the good functioning and stability of the financial sector in Europe. Cooperation with national regulators is absolutely essential. That is why we believe that they should be provided with adequate financing that respects their current challenges, including relocation or assignation of the new tasks. At the same time, we must push for increased efficiency of ISAs. Last but not least, ECON is also calling for adequate resources, for example for the coordination and surveillance of the macroeconomic policies of the Member States’ fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and other areas.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her  So, now I have a microphone. I was still in the middle of writing down my notes, so now you catch me a bit surprised. Thank you very much for the first time, Mr Löger, for your presence. It is an honour that the Finance Minister presenting the Council's position is actually with us. We are not used to that at all. Once again, on behalf of my fellow Members, I would like to express my thanks for your presence. It shows how seriously you take the debate over the European budget. I'm grateful for that , but it's going to be a fight. I listen to you, and I hear you stress that the Council is increasing the budget because you are taking last year's budget in comparison. However, it is now the case that the Commission has, of course, proposed even more substantial efforts, which we have welcomed, and you are cutting back, not in areas that are comprehensible in terms of content, but in areas where it is otherwise stressed that the innovative nature of the European Union is of great importance – and here you are cutting back for the sake of shortening.  That is why the Committee on Industry has withdrawn all these cuts. We cannot understand 300 million in the European research programme, for example, and certainly not in the area of social challenges. We want to reintroduce the budget figures that have been cut by EFSI, we want to achieve the EU's sustainable development goals, and we are in favour of a clear distinction between research funding in the field of civil and military tasks. That is why our aim is to obtain new additives for military research.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, Europe is facing a lot of challenges – from the rise of populism, to the impact of new technologies, to the refugees that have to be integrated – and the budget is supposed to be our solution to these problems. That is why it is a bit surprising that we are not making bigger cuts, reprioritisation and relocation. Everything seems to be as important as last year, but it cannot be, because the world is rapidly changing, it has changed. But the good thing about this budget is its support to the Single Market. The Single Market is our biggest success. It is actually the core of this business – the possibility to move to another country, to work, to study, to export, import – that is what this Union is about. That is why I am supporting this budget and that is why the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) is very glad for the support it has been given.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. –Madam President, I very much agree especially with what the Commissioner has said, that we need to set the priorities, and we have set them to maintain them as priorities. In fact, should we ask the public – and we do have surveys – what they consider to be a priority, transport usually is ranked among the highest. There is where people see a real difference being made by the European Union. In transport, with significant long-term projects, what matters is continuity and stability. By the way, in transport we have one of the biggest successes of the European Union: CEF, SESAR... these are issues which are widely recognised. We strongly support also what the Budget Committee has finalised and what has been voted, and we were looking at it primarily from the perspective that we should deliver on those legitimate priorities that we have set and the legislation which is in place and will be put in place in the course of these months. One final remark: we would also support minor issues like passenger rights where there is very little awareness, this is insignificant money but just to say that sometimes it is also about small issues.

name: John HOWARTH
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Madam President, in the Committee on Budgets (BUDG), as my friend Daniele Viotti said, we talk of delivering European Union added value. In the Committee on Regional Development (REGI), on which I also sit, we talk about cohesion policy delivering European priorities and here the twains meet very productively. Every euro we invest in cohesion policy delivers a return on investment of 174%. Less investment in cohesion policy means lower growth and fewer jobs. That is why we believe in Regional Development that cohesion funds must remain the main investment priority of the European Union with an ambitious budget to match ambitious goals. Secondly, after a period of under—implementation, the programmes have now reached cruising speed. So, while I note the 1.1% increase in payment appropriations, we wonder if this will be sufficient and raise a note of caution that we may need a higher level of payments to match the pace of the programmes. Finally, we note with caution the proposal to increase the budget of the Structural Reform Support Programme by EUR 80 million over the next two budget years. We would firmly state that this needs to be achieved through the mobilisation of special instruments and not at the expense of cohesion policy.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, I am replacing my colleague Morten Løkkegaard from ALDE because he could not be here tonight. The main plea of the Culture Committee is to budget up. We know there’s a lot of scepticism toward elites in Europe and with our programmes for education, culture, media and inclusion via cultural and cultural diversity, we reach out to individuals. I think that is very important in the current situation. We have very good programmes and we want to budget up Erasmus in 2019 by even 15% because we can show that it is a very successful programme, a flagship programme, and the same with creative Europe, the culture programme. I’m just back from the film festivals in Europe and we have to support our European films, not to leave it to Hollywood and Bollywood. And we know that media freedom and media plurality to a certain extent are endangered in the European Union, so we should do the utmost to foster them and to have really quality journalism all over the European Union.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, I am speaking in my capacity as Vice-Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO). We would like to highlight two points in relation to the budget. Firstly, 2019 is not only the year of the European elections but it could also be the first year after the withdrawal of a Member State. Therefore, it is of paramount importance to keep the communication with European citizens open. We have to increase our efforts to engage them and mobilise them to vote in these elections. We have to make sure that next year’s budget contains the necessary resources to respond to citizens’ expectations. Secondly, it is very disappointing that the Council has once again made unnecessary cuts to the programmes in the area of citizenship. The Council did so despite these programmes’ excellent implementation rates. In AFCO, we are now very happy to see that the Committee on Budgets has followed our recommendation and has restored all lines at least to the level of the draft budget.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities. – Madam President, I also replace my colleague Maline Björk, author of the opinion. We underline some femm proposals: strengthening cohesion funds to safeguard women's economic and social rights, combating feminisation of poverty, investing in high-quality public care services, strengthening sex education policies and sexual and reproductive health services, combating all forms of violence against women and girls , combating trafficking in human beings which mainly affects women and girls in sordid sexual exploitation businesses. Proposals that, for the most part, unfortunately, the Committee on Budgets has failed, rejecting the need for a budget sensitive to inequalities between men and women. Proposals that highlight the limitations of this budget proposal, replicating the options of the current multiannual financial framework and which could be aggravated in the next with the option of further cuts in cohesion, increasing the security and militaristic headings with consequences that inevitably have a particular impact on women. For this reason, our committee has put forward all the sinker proposals for which it requests support in the vote. Thank you.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, also the Council, rapporteur Daniel Viotti and all the shadows.  There is a good climate, a good atmosphere. I hope it goes on. We are waiting for lengthy negotiations and therefore in favour of the Europeans that there will be good agreement in the negotiations ahead.  Parliament, parliament's moderates, the groups in favour of the integration of the European Union, are united and united in favour of citizens. We have a small budget, 1% of gross domestic product, but a budget that has a huge impact on citizens' lives. Unfortunately, it is not always felt and we should all work to make it more visible in terms of the impact and positive effect it has, a truly investment budget. About 94% of the budget is for investment and only 6% is for current expenditure and a budget also for young people, for farmers, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for research, for innovation, for economic growth.  These are our priorities and we therefore hope and we are sure that we will achieve, within the limits and that 1% of the Gross National Income of the European Union, a good agreement for the citizens and the challenges that we face ahead. That's what they demand of us.

name: Karine GLOANEC MAURIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, our colleague Daniele Viotti presents today before this assembly the draft report on the budget for the year 2019. This report defends all of our priority envelopes. I fully agree with the work done by our rapporteur and congratulate him, once again, warmly. But that has been said, we are discussing today the last annual budget of this mandate. A budgetary procedure is always eminently political; it is even more so. While, in relation to the Commission's proposal, Mr Minister, the Council is still proposing reductions of a level never reached before, and the European Union has never faced so many questions about its future, I will have the great honour of representing our Parliament during the budgetary conciliation procedure that will open after this vote. My mandate will be very clear: to give the whole of European society, young people, project leaders, businesses, researchers, farmers, the means it needs to make our Europe live in a dignified, efficient way, in line with the current economic and ecological challenges. Territorial cohesion, the fight against youth unemployment, the reception of refugees, aid to the energy transition, the fight against global warming: progress needs ambitious funding. European citizens have expressed this many times: they demand a responsible attitude from us. Let's not disappoint them.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Oettinger, I would like to thank commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Your proposal for the 2019 budget provided for an increase in the budget of around 3% compared to 2018. This sum has now been increased by EUR 700 million in the Committee on Budgets. I believe that it is the wrong signal to simply keep calling for more money, without, quite specifically, giving life to the priorities that are being set.  There are good reasons to spend more money on some areas. The areas of security, migration, energy policy, but also innovation and research deserve to be funded generously. However, this does not necessarily mean that you have to spend more money at the same time. Of course, there are also ways of freeing up money elsewhere by redeploying and saving, so that you don't need more money. I think it is a fallacy when Mr Fernandes, for example, has just said that it is a case of joining forces when we are there for the citizens and spend more money. It has to be said that this money that is to be spent here is taken from the citizens beforehand – taken away by taxes. This money does not fall from the sky. I am therefore convinced that the citizens will thank us if we use this money very sparingly.  That is what we should do, and we should also define the measures that we want to implement in a measurable way and then have the courage to say afterwards: have these purposes actually made a difference, or have these objectives been achieved at all? That is quite crucial. We cannot simply define measures that look beautiful on paper.  I believe that we must finally do more for subsidiarity in the budgetary field too. The EU should not be responsible for all sorts of things. As a result, we have a lot of pots, and as a result we lose the transparency of this budget and, in the end, we do not get better, but worse.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my group strongly supports the guidelines and priorities proposed by our rapporteur-general, Mr Viotti. We support the priority given to investment, research, innovation, and increased support funding for SMEs, in particular the COSME programme. We support the strengthening of resources for young people by providing additional funding to Erasmus and continuing the Youth Employment Initiative. We want much more resources to be spent on combating global warming. The IPCC has just issued a solemn warning: there is an urgent need for our planet to remain habitable and manageable. We also, of course, want additional resources to be provided for border control, migration management, cooperation between police forces and the fight against terrorism. In conclusion, I would like to focus on three points. I think we have to send a very clear warning to Mr Erdogan in the light of his autocratic frenzy. Therefore, I support the reduction of pre-accession appropriations for Turkey, without however challenging the $3 billion requested for refugees. The resources of UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, must be strengthened. It is not by depriving hundreds of thousands of Palestinian children of school that we will contribute to the achievement of peace. Mr. Trump is wrong and his mistakes must be corrected.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I see with satisfaction that the Parliament’s reading of next year’s budget reverses almost all of the cuts proposed by the Council. Some of them being of an unprecedented scope and by no means justified by absorption capacity. Thus, programmes related to some of our priorities – youth employment, research, biodiversity and climate, development cooperation, neighbourhood – will be reinforced, bringing the budget closer to the priorities that were agreed here in our March resolution. Moreover, the proposal contains excellent pilot projects and preparatory actions. I want to thank the rapporteur for his consensual approach on that. However, I regret that there is too strong a reference to defence spending, and a clear endorsement of defence programmes. Furthermore, the multiple references to migration do not speak to a coherent and humanist approach from the European Union. Despite this and other shortcomings, the Parliament’s position to be adopted this week should be a good basis for the final negotiation with the Council.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, this year again this budget is a budget in crisis and a budget constrained, but Brexit has a bit of a good back because the reality is that the European Union budget is in perpetual crisis. As you know, the gap between budget registrations and reality has always widened and we have a duty of sincerity towards European citizens. We must tell them that the hundreds of billions registered, the European dreams sold in this budget will hardly all be realized, because this requires additional efforts of the States, which may not be there. This part of budget fiction is unethical and does not help with clarity and if I were unpleasant, I would say it is a deception. For the rest, this budget is unsurprising: it focuses on defence and security, it does not provide any additional means for the fight against poverty, nor does it meet the new requirements for the fight against climate change and the loss of biodiversity. Let us continue in this way, continue from year to year, and the distrust of the European peoples towards the European Union will only grow.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I largely agree with the priorities identified by the rapporteur, starting with sustainable growth, the fight against climate change, action for small businesses and research, aid for Africa – to really help where there is a problem, namely that of immigration, and we must use resources, all available resources – and, above all, the fight against poverty. , the poverty of European citizens. The key question is whether we will be able to do without a greater contribution from the Member States – I am doing a good thing to the rapporteur and to this Parliament in order to succeed in doing so – and, since we want to give a signal to the citizens, we are calling for a whole series of spending reviews and cuts, especially in administrative expenditure, starting with the privileges of Members and Commissioners. , where we should cut tens of millions of euros, up to lease contracts, where we can find cuts of EUR 300 million, up to the contributions to parties and foundations, EUR 70 million, which we could convey to these voices and perhaps convey even more than this Parliament is asking for.

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the old days, the idea of the Union was to increase economic freedom and reduce taxes and burden citizens. Today, the main objective of this Parliament is to increase the Union budget and force Member States to increase taxes and burdens. The closer you get to the election, the more you show off spending someone else's money. Taking money from hardworking people to fight unemployment, support selected entrepreneurs, or pay scholarships to selected students. In fact, you create unemployment, you destroy the economy and all people's activity. After all, North Korea will not be out of the question. There, 100% of the revenue is already taken for these purposes. At most, communist countries catch up. You will achieve their standard of economic development and lack of unemployment. After all, Europe will experience the happiness of economic emigration to China or Singapore. I do not wish you luck.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, I would also like to welcome Minister Löger to the European Parliament this evening. This year we are sharing the priorities for the budget of the Union for next year, exactly as we shared them for this year. The Council and Parliament, together we say that the economy is important and competitiveness is important, we want more growth and more jobs, and research and innovation are important. But we go on two different paths. The Parliament, under the leadership of Daniele Viotti, will propose adequate, realistic increases where money is needed; while the Council, pretending that competitiveness, research and innovation is important, reduces the amounts foreseen for Horizon 2020 by EUR 300 million. This worsens competitiveness in Europe and endangers research and innovation. Minister Löger, this is why I would really call on you in the following negotiations to move closer to Parliament’s position so that we can adequately finance these important areas, which we have jointly agreed are important. If we agree that something is important, we have to finance it adequately as well. Secondly, I would like to draw colleagues’ attention to one of the amendments which I have put forward. It foresees the allocation of EUR 50 million in the position of the Parliament in Heading 2 for combating swine fever in Europe, because in several Member States we are seeing this dangerous disease which affects farmers in Europe. I would like to call on the Commission and the Council to foresee the amounts needed. People and farmers are in need. We have to stand by their side if they are in need. The Union has to be by their side.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – Our main priorities are clear: sustainable growth, innovation, competitiveness, security, the fight against climate change, the transition to renewable energy, migration, but also a specific focus on young people. Our development strategies are intended to help us create new quality jobs, improve quality of life, reduce poverty and social exclusion. Paradoxically, on the one hand, we know where the way to achieve our objectives leads, on the other hand, the Council proposes cuts to those programmes which are intended to increase the competitiveness and innovation of the Union economy. As regards payments, Member States must comply with the basic rules on economic governance and budgetary discipline and fulfil what they have committed themselves to. At the same time, we must make it clear to citizens that if the country puts money into the common budget, it will save in public finances. In the budget negotiations, the Council's reluctance to finance the priorities it has previously endorsed is repeated every year. The only solution is to change today's complicated, opaque and, for many countries, unfair budget financing system. That is why Monti's high group for the new own resources system was established. It also represented members of the Council, members of the Commission and members of the European Parliament. They worked for many years. They prepared a great project and agreed on its recommendations. Therefore, when creating a new multiannual financial framework and a strategy for new own resources, no institution should make excuses for disagreeing with monti group conclusions.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Speaking in this debate, I would like to emphasise that the Committee on Budgets voted by a large majority on more than 1900 amendments to the Council's position, which resulted not only in the withdrawal of all council cuts, but also in an increase in commitment appropriations of more than EUR 720 million. The most significant increases relate to the allocation of EUR 350 million to the Youth Employment Initiative and nearly EUR 130 million to the Security and Citizenship heading. However, it appears that an increase of only 3.2% in the level of payments compared to 2018 may not be sufficient, as 2019 is the penultimate year of the current financial perspective and thus will accumulate payments, outstanding accounts already known to the Commission from previous years. Nevertheless, a budget as such should address the internal and external dimensions of migration, strengthen the protection of the Union's external borders, stimulate economic growth, promote employment and job creation, especially for young people, and strengthen the effective cohesion of the Union and agriculture.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, in discussing next year’s EU budget I would like to draw your attention to several topics. Firstly, concerning the budget of the European Parliament. The overall figure is at a level of EUR 1.999 billion. Thus Parliament’s share of Heading 5 will stay at the level of 18.5%, which is the lowest in the last 15 years. Secondly, concerning the budgets of other institutions. Their importance for the implementation of the Union’s policies is significant. If we want these institutions to function with the highest possible effectiveness they should be properly financed. We propose to restore the cuts to the budgets of the European Court of Justice, the Committee of the Regions, the Economic and Social Committee and the European External Action Service, with some upper adjustments. Within Section III there are drastic cuts to the lines related to Turkeyʼs IPA II funds. From the Commission’s proposed draft budget of EUR 244.1 million for the ‘Support for political reforms’ line, the Council has cut almost 60% of the sum. There is an extra decrease of EUR 66.8 million on the other two lines, while EUR 50 million of them are linked to the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, which is against the interests of the Union. Our opinion is that these cuts would deprive the Commission of its leverage to properly manage relations between the EU and Turkey. It will ultimately have a negative effect on Brussels—Ankara relations. Finally, excluding the excessive and unjustified cuts, we believe that the overall approach to next year’s budget is correct and we expect our position to be maintained during the conciliation process.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, the European budget will be 166 billion in commitment appropriations. But let us not forget the real commitments to European society. The first of these: equality. The Committee on Budgets rejected the budget lines proposed by the #MeToo against sexual harassment in the European Parliament. The second: transparency. The Committee on Budgets also lay down amendments calling for more transparency in Members' departures, cutting pay scales — the highest ones - rather than firing people, or cutting certain unnecessary comforts. And I wonder: can't MPs' asses fly for two hours in economy class? The third priority: employment. It is increasingly difficult for young people to find a stable future. Direct investment from Europe is needed in transforming and boosting the productive fabric and in the care economy. There are more priorities, of course, but the question will now be whether we will abandon the path of austerity or continue on that... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Madam President, 2019 should have been the final year that the UK paid anything to the EU and yet somehow the EU budget is increasing, and could now be above EUR 164 billion for next year alone. You should be preparing for the UK’s withdrawal, but you have your head in the sand and want to spend even more taxpayers’ money. But I suppose there is good reason, isn’t there? The Tories’ surrender to the EU on every aspect of the Brexit negotiations has meant Theresa May agreeing to give the EU GBP 40 billion for nothing in return, which could take decades for the British taxpayers to pay off. Yet at home, the same Tory party says there is not enough money and makes damaging cuts to front-line public services. The British negotiators need to remember that the UK is not legally obliged to pay the EU anything after we leave, yet the Conservatives are negotiating a never-ending transitional agreement, meaning the British people will continue having to make vast contributions but without any representation or democratic way to change your decisions. The Tories are negotiating a Brexit that is even worse than if we’d remained a member, and now we discover that Mrs May, as part of her abject surrender to Mr Barnier, is going to commit us to spending an additional GBP 20 billion for the next framework. One pound is too much. There should not be one penny, one pfennig, one centime. If we look at how the EU spends our money in the UK it’s clear what’s going on: EUR 300 000 to the European Alternatives Group; EUR 350 000 to the European Movement, and in 2017 the My Life My Say Group received EUR 15 000. The list goes on. All these groups oppose Brexit and are doing everything they can to overturn the referendum. You often talk about foreign interference... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: André ELISSEN
text: Mr President, today we are discussing the 2019 budget, now with the Council's position. Once again, we have failed to make necessary, major cuts. The departure of net contributor Uk and the growing dissatisfaction of European citizens about the money-wasting EU does not interest the EU elite at all. I was hoping that the European Parliament would demand substantial cuts to the budget of – mind you – EUR 164 billion, but even minimal cuts would be voted down by the Europhiles among us. Another missed opportunity, for example, to cut the generous salaries and allowances of civil servants and parliamentarians. The EU depends on fraud-prone subsidies, which seriously distort market conditions. The so-called European values, which Europeans are being forced upon with all these subsidies, are at the expense of the common man's wallet. In Austria and Italy, the electorate has already spoken clearly. We look forward to the European elections next year with great confidence.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to thank the main rapporteur, Daniele Viotti, and my colleagues for the excellent cooperation that has allowed us to find really good and meaningful compromises together. I am also pleased that we can be so strong and united in the priorities. In my view, this means, above all, that we must keep a close eye on innovation and competition and that we still have programmes in the field of science, where excellent projects are submitted, but because of the underfunding of the programmes there are not enough funding options and the rejection rates are up to 95.96 %, although it is not due to the quality of the scientific projects. , but because of the lack of funding. As a second priority, I think it is very important that we take a closer look at the issue of Erasmus and the Discover EU issue and that we are aware that the European Union is built on a young generation that should understand each other, get to know the EU, get to know different countries and benefit accordingly. The final point, for me, is still the issue of security and migration, where we must adequately equip our agencies to carry out their tasks.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As one of the youngest Members of this House, I must stress once again that I still think it is very right and important that we, as the European Union, have committed ourselves to the fight against youth unemployment and have rightly made this issue a priority.  With the Erasmus+ programme, we enable millions of Europeans to travel abroad, get to know other cultures, train, gain new work experience or live the European Voluntary Service. We give all these people the opportunity to be united in diversity. That is why it is quite rightly the Motto of the European Union here, or a priority of the European Parliament, to support the young generation. With the Employment Initiative, we are bringing young people back to work. The unemployment rates of young people in the European Union are still far too high. If Europe's youth is to have a future, or if Europe is to have a future, then we must give Europe's youth a future, and this draft of Parliament makes that very, very clear.  I hope that by increasing the funding for the fight against youth unemployment by 350 million and increasing the Erasmus+ programme by 360 million, we will send a clear signal to the Heads of State or Government.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, I think we are on an important point. Do we dare to make choices? Do we dare to delete the things that the European Union should not do anymore? Delete the things that she doesn't do well, so that we can free up money to start investing in new priorities? What do I set for next year's budget? The best incentive to be economical is to ensure that the European budget does not increase. Nevertheless, the European Parliament is proposing to put an additional 721 million on top of the Commission proposal in that European budget. Secondly, we should listen to the experts, the European Court of Auditors. What do they say? That we need real objectives based on European added value. What do we see? In this budget, inflation, a constant inflation of ever-new targets, is again a constant one. Is it all bad news? No. There are also good things in this draft budget: more investment in research, in Erasmus, in safety, in Frontex. Very important, but may it be a little more with a little more ambition.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Madam President, on the eve of the European elections, we must send a clear and voluntary message to the citizens. So let us respond to their impatience by strengthening a Europe that speaks to them because it prepares for their future and because it protects them. Preparing for the future means making research a priority, investing in education and vocational training through Erasmus, it is offering all young people the opportunity to meet European diversity. Protecting Europeans means taking stock of migration challenges and having appropriate funds to control external borders - Frontex and ASO - is about building constructive relations with African countries, the Balkans, the Middle East, it is preserving the climate. Protecting Europeans means giving substance to structured cooperation in defence and security, it is mobilizing the necessary means to combat the challenges and threats that globalisation poses to us and which States can no longer assume alone at the national level. The 2019 budget...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank first of all, Mr Viotti and Mr Grum for their report on the 2019 budget and congratulate them. First of all, I welcome Mr Viotti's commitment to youth, because in the face of the dramatic increase in applications under the Erasmus programme, a victim of its success, the Council's position remains well below and is almost indecent in the face of needs. Similarly, youth unemployment in Europe continues to peak at 15%. The youth employment programmes and the European Social Fund are now recognised as powerful tools. I therefore welcome my colleagues' proposal to spend an additional EUR 580 million on the Youth Employment Initiative. The same goes for rural development, which is subject to a reduction of more than EUR 310 million in commitments compared to the Commission's project, which was already drastically cutting the funds allocated to this envelope. Yet agricultural policies can be structuring in the fight against climate change, even when we do not even reach the 20% commitments made even before the signing of the Paris conference. I therefore welcome the rapporteurs' proposal to increase this envelope by EUR 20 million.  Similarly, we must strongly support their proposal to speed up the implementation of the programmes of political cohesion, which are consubstantial of the Union - I would even say that are the DNA of the European Union - and which forge the solidarity of our territories and our citizens. The proposals put forward by the Commission and the Council are neither up to the ambitions nor up to the needs that the European Union must meet in these times of crisis of confidence. The budget retains deficiencies that are the main cause, and I preach a little here for my parish, an inappropriate and undersized multi-year financial framework. The same mistakes should not be repeated in the future.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, the Europe we are seeking is a strong Europe. For Europe to be strong, it needs a strong social and development Europe, a Europe of young people. That is why we support the funds for youth employment, for innovation, Horizon 2020, for Erasmus, for small and medium-sized enterprises, a Europe that responds to challenges, a Europe with strong defence and security so that it can effectively defend the sovereignty of the Member States. As the Council rightly said, we must respect taxpayers' money because they are the ones who are strengthening the budget. And I ask: how much do we respect the money of european taxpayers when the European Union funds countries that violate the principles and values of the European Union, that provoke Member States of the European Union, that hold part of European Union member countries, such as Turkey? How can we talk about a credible, strong Europe, when we apply double standards for sanctions, when we continue to show tolerance in this country? I propose freezing funds for Turkey until it respects international and European law.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, for the European Union to have a future, young people must have a future and have jobs. And if we all mean it, we should support it when it is in front of us and not just when we speak publicly in the European Parliament. But I'm going to move on to another matter. It is very strange to me that the Presiding Country of the European Union has a very correct position: that Turkey should not even be in accession because it does not even meet the Copenhagen political criteria. Secondly, Turkey has commitments to the European Union concerning, inter alia, the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus. We're all talking about our common home. Our common home - and our principles and values - that we are talking about, has a room which it illegally owns ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner and President-in-Office, it is a given, and you have heard this before: the European Union cannot finance Turkey. Turkey holds 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, has occupied another Member State, threatens Greece constantly with casus belli, if Greece extends its territorial waters to 12 miles, threatens it with war, violates Greek territorial waters, violates Greek airspace. Is it possible for the European Union to finance Turkey? Not. We are proposing a freeze on European Union funds for Turkey. At the same time, you are giving funds to the Western Balkans, to Skopje, where there is an of corruption. Recently we have had intimidation, threats and bribery procedures in order for Mr Zaev to find 80 Members to pass ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, almost at the end of a procedure in the Parliament I must say I do like this budget. I like it for its youth focus, for the targets set on migration and its future spending in research and defence, and that is why the rapporteur should be applauded. I heard carefully the Commissioner and I appreciate his sympathetic approach towards climate change. However, we need to translate words into money and therefore into action. Finally, yet importantly, in the symbolism of our rapporteur being Italian, allow me to dare to say the realpolitik of an Italian budget should definitely not become the one of the EU budget, and contrary to Mr Salvini’s hopes, we are not going to use this budget for electioneering but for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly thanks to the rapporteur and also Commissioner Oettinger, who has been so dutiful and direct and clear in his portfolio in this regard, I complement him on that. In the budget itself I think it is absolutely vital that everything we do has added value. That has to be the essential ingredient of the European Union and I’d particularly like to see emphasis being put on helping SMEs: I think due to the policies over the last number of years going back to Michel Barnier, when he was Regional Development Commissioner bringing in policies, SMEs are now in a position to develop and grow but many of them have difficulty in accessing funding. I hosted a seminar in my own county in Tralee in Kerry a few weeks ago on investEu, and that message came across and we need to make it simpler for them to do that. I also agree with the Commissioner that we have to give leadership in climate change: a lot of research will be required and in Europe in particular we’ve got to do a lot of that, so the rest of the world will follow.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Minister Löger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In short, we have noted the expectations, concerns, priorities and specific concerns of today's debate and will carry them out in depth in the coming days.  On the basis of this vote, after the vote here in the House and before the conciliation procedure begins, we want to respond to your concerns and show you, through written communications, what impact the expectations made today in euros and cents for which programmes are. We will also provide the information requested by Parliament on conditional reserves in order, i hope, to be able to agree on a 2019 budget without reserves, thereby avoiding further implementation steps, for example. We believe that the differences – here the Council, here the Commission, here Parliament – are manageable; we are talking about EUR 2.5 billion, which is 1.6% of the total budget. With goodwill, which I would like to attest to all of you here and also to appeal to the Commission, we have a good chance of reaching an agreement within the deadline set by the Treaty. In other words, from today until 19 November, everyone should work towards this.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has I am pleased that I have had the opportunity to have a very impulsive debate today and to hear a very broad debate on many expectations for this 2019 budget. I believe that we are all aware that the work of the rapporteurs is also very intensive, and I would like to take this opportunity to take the opportunity to manage the process for further discussions in this form in a professional and also disciplined form. I recognise that it is, of course, a question of perspective whether you want to see an increase in this Council proposal of 2%, or whether you are talking about cuts, so to speak, in line with the Commission's proposal here or there. I believe that it will be necessary to find this common perspective on the various issues. And I also think I can speak from experience that it will be necessary to talk about one side of costs and the other side of investment. It will be up to all of us to make a clear distinction between where we have the opportunity to save – in the responsibility of the citizens – and where we have a shared responsibility to make investments that also add value to the European Union and, above all, to added value for taxpayers and, therefore, all Europeans in this form. I am pleased that, in view of the political framework for the 2019 EU election, we are also going into the discussion of the next few weeks in a responsible and sensible way, and I can see my visit here in Parliament today as a positive investment for myself, because I am confident that these many contributions will continue to be implemented well in the coming weeks. Thank you very much for that.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is, of course, difficult to enclose the conclusions of such a long debate in two minutes. I will concentrate on a few issues, taking for granted – they will forgive me if I do so quickly – my thanks to Commissioner Oettinger and Mr Loger for their speech and contribution, as well as to all the members who have spoken. I would like to make two very, very quick reflections, since I cannot go into the substance of the individual issues. Minister, I am not telling you, Commissioner Oettinger has told you this and other Members have told you that there are cuts in the budget presented by the Commission, there are no increases. We can always play the game of seeing the glass half full or half empty: we see it half empty, you probably see it half full. It is in the middle, exactly, we have to decide whether that glass is half full or half empty, but the Commissioner tells him and we tell him: these funds are not enough. We need a budget that really meets the needs that already exist today and which the Commission has highlighted.  Thank you for your reference to compliance with the agreements. This Parliament has always respected the agreements and intends to respect them again from now on. In conclusion, on the subject of agreements, I would like to thank Commissioner Oettinger, who wanted to address the issue of the refugee instrument for Turkey, a measure which we fully support and on which, here too, we want to refer and we want to refer to the agreements that have already taken place between the institutions, that is to say in the first version proposed by the Commission. Finally, on the issue of emergencies, Minister, emergencies are dealt with with emergency funds, they are not dealt with by setting aside money for emergencies that we do not know if there will be, hoping that they will never be there. And finally, this Parliament, me first as well as the whole Commission, will use until the last minute, we want to use until the last minute useful to reach an agreement and in this will find an ally for sure.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Finally, I would also like to express my sincere thanks for the open and honest debate. We all know that next year we will have to defend democracy in Europe, and the budget naturally plays an essential role here. Public relations and "do good and talk about it" must be at the heart of our deliberations. I recently had a conversation with Euronews, a television channel that is therefore intensively shaping the European media area, and I believe that it is our job to deliver good results to the citizens. With this in mind, I would like to thank you for the really fruitful discussion and I hope that we will achieve a good result for our citizens in the conciliation procedure.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 24 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to stress that a modern, focused EU budget cannot be achieved without including a clear and comprehensive gender dimension, which is essential to enable better and more evidence-based solutions, which in turn help to ensure the effective use of public funds and EU added value for all EU actions. I would also like to call for an increase in resources, such as the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the EU Cohesion Fund, in order to guarantee women's economic and social rights, in particular through measures in the field of women's employment and by investing in high-quality affordable public care services, and reducing gender inequalities, including through current measures at Union and Member State level and by a separate budget line for this purpose. It is also essential to provide appropriations to support women's entrepreneurship and to ensure women's access to loans and equity under European Union programmes and funds such as COSME, Horizon 2020 and the European Social Fund. It is also essential to ensure equal participation of girls and young women in the YOUTH Employment Initiative and to focus on their quality training and employment offers, including in the digital economy, ICT and science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. - The European Union budget is an instrument for the performance of European policies. It must address the priorities of European citizens and ensure that the objectives we set are achieved. I welcome the fact that the rapporteur did not accept the play of the Council and the Commission, whose proposals were at insufficient levels, and proposed to increase the budget. Thanks to my faction, the European Parliament will go into negotiations with the Council with a plan that foresees an increase in funding for erasmus+, the Youth Employment Facility and the European Child Guarantee against Poverty. I also welcome the increase in climate change. The European Union has been underperforming in this field, even after repeated retries, for many years. If we tolerate failure to live up to our own commitments, we will undermine our image in the eyes of the citizens and waste the time we have left to take the necessary adaptation and mitigation measures. On the contrary, I regret that my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets did not listen to my requests and did not increase efsa's resources. The Agency will objectively need a higher budget in the context of its work in the field of pesticides, among other things. In this case, not securing a sufficient amount of budget is tantamount to endangering nature, but also to the health of all of us.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Michel Dantin's report on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection on the quality of water for human consumption (COM(2017)0753 – C8-0019/2018 - 2017/0332 (COD)) (A8-0288/2018).

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the shadow rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, let me now thank the negotiating team of this Parliament and the services of the European Commission for the work we have done together. Tomorrow we will vote on the report on the revision of the Directive on the quality of drinking water in Europe. The aim of this directive is to revise the quality parameters of drinking water and to propose a new method of risk assessment to prevent the dangers and risks of pollutants further upstream. Almost 20 years after its entry into force, the revision of the Drinking Water Directive is now needed to align quality parameters with advances in science and to take into account emerging substances. I believe that we have adopted in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety a coherent report which defends the interests of European citizens, takes into account the strong constraints of suppliers, Member States and local authorities, but also strongly supports the European Commission's risk-based approach. We all agree: access to quality water is a necessity for Europe, a necessity for its citizens. Promoting access to quality water for European citizens at an affordable cost, in full transparency towards the European consumer, is also a requirement that we can share. This report therefore presents several major issues: access to water, public accountability and finally the quality parameters required by the revised directive. With regard to access to water, the provision of quality water is, of course, a priority that we share, but I regret that the European Commission has included the issue of access to water in the revision of the Drinking Water Directive, thus blurring the first message on the quality of water distributed in Europe. Too many citizens still unjustly doubt the quality of tap water. Of course, our Member States are different in their institutional functioning and in their physical reality, and we must take this diversity into account.  Parliament's report is already going beyond the European Commission's ambitions for access to water by proposing that Member States promote universal access to water, i.e. access to water for all in the European Union. I am pleased to have succeeded in integrating this balance which respects the principle of subsidiarity and which I will be able to defend in the trilogue negotiations. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has spoken out in favour of increasing transparency and public information on the quality of distributed water. The quality and price of water are elements that must be brought to the consumer's attention, both to preserve the resource and to promote the consumption of tap water before bottled water. However, I would like to draw the attention of the European Commission and the Council to the fact that the objective of transparency must be at the service of water quality and consumer education and not the disclosure of sensitive information, both from an economic and strategic point of view, which presents in the context in which we currently live , a security risk. With regard to quality parameters, I regret, ladies and gentlemen, that the World Health Organisation, the institution of reference for pollutants and health protection, has not had more echoes in the original proposal and in the debates in the European Parliament. In a particularly sensitive context in terms of health security, the challenge for the European institutions today is to assess the risks associated with each pollutant as best as possible. I find it surprising, to say the least, that WHO, which is often used as a reference by our institution for more constraints, is now short-circuited by those who wish to amend the report in order to reduce the reference value for some of the hazardous substances, particularly chemical compounds such as endocrine disruptors and perfluorates. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is time to revise a directive that is so important to our people after 20 years - yes 20 years. Ladies and gentlemen, the ideal can bring us together, pragmatism and realism may divide us; to move forward, I join this second camp.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to first warmly thank MEP Michel Dantin and all the shadow rapporteurs for the hard work done on the proposal for a revised Drinking Water Directive. The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s work and the fact that the European Parliament’s amendments are largely aligned with the main elements of our proposal. I would like to recall that the main objective of our proposal is to ensure the safety of drinking water in the European Union for the 21st century. We should be proud that today, most people living in the EU enjoy drinking water that is of the highest standards worldwide. This is the result of over thirty years of successful EU drinking water policies and rules. The proposal builds on this success but recognises that change is necessary if we want to ensure that this remains the case for the next 20 years. Besides, it fulfils the Commission’s response to the citizens’ Right2Water initiative. It is very important that you get a mandate from the plenary tomorrow to start trilogues. In this respect, I can assure you that the Commission is doing its utmost to help the Austrian Presidency and Member States to reach a common ground so that negotiations can start as soon as possible. Let me also underline that, in acting as an honest broker to facilitate an agreement between the co-legislators, the Commission would uphold the important objective of this proposal, which I believe we all share. I know that on some issues, political opinions differ, such as the question of how best to ensure access to water and the issue of the strictness of health standards. These questions are crucial for European citizens, and the solutions we propose will bring positive change to their daily life. I have taken good note of the latest amendments tabled. Let me therefore once again call on the Parliament to support the Commission’s ambition to protect even better the health of our citizens by proposing strict health standards. Let me also call on you to agree on rules on access to water – which are ambitious and workable at the same time – in order to ensure that our citizens across the EU truly have better access to this indispensable resource.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I think it is a good idea for citizens to receive free, high-quality drinking water in public places, in restaurants, in public places throughout the European Union in the future. But a good idea can also be ruined by prescribing it centrally from Brussels without supplying the necessary money. There are also legal questions as to whether we can really prescribe this. That is why I think that we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats think the Commission's proposal is a good one. We should support the local authorities and many in the European Union. The Member States should support the provision of free drinking water, because I believe that we should not and cannot prescribe this. I think that Michel Dantin and the Committee on the Environment have produced a good report. It strikes a balance between the costs to local authorities and the urgent need to protect our water even better. It is already the safest and most controlled food in the European Union. We should not exaggerate, all of this must be proportionate. However, I believe that we can support in good conscience what the committee has presented. I hope that tomorrow we will reject the far-reaching amendments tabled by the Social Democrats and others and vote in favour of Michel Dantin's report by a large majority.

name: Rory PALMER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, firstly can I thank the rapporteur, Mr Dantin, for all his work, and indeed the shadow rapporteurs from the other Groups, all our staff and the Commission officials as well, for all their work on this complex, wide-ranging report. I think most of us take it for granted that when we turn on the tap, the tap water in our glass will be clean, safe and high quality, so of course, protecting public health and the safety of the public must be the foremost objective of this Directive, and thatʼs the leading priority for my Group. On endocrine disruptors, the S&D Group pushed, as we have done for a number of years, for stronger protections by bringing those substances into the formal parametric values. On PFAS substances we have been clear that stronger action is needed, and we are determined to see controls of microplastics in water as well. We must also take this opportunity, in my view, to not just criticise water suppliers for unacceptable leakage rates; we must also mandate action with targets to reduce leakage. Leakage is bad for customers. It sees bills going up – 2.4 billion litres of water is wasted in my own Member State every single day – so I applaud the GMB Trade Unionʼs campaign to take back the tap, to get water in the UK back in public hands, working in the interests of people and not shareholder dividends. Earlier I talked about the fact that we take it for granted that tap water coming out of our taps is safe – but what about those who have no taps? People in refugee camps in our cities, people who are homeless. I applaud the fact that the Commission takes this opportunity to respond to the Citizens’ Initiative signed by 1.8 million people. It would be a missed opportunity if this Parliament did not match the ambition of the Commission on the right to water. In fact, my view is that this Parliament should be strengthening and adding to that ambition, not watering it down. We have to make the right to water a reality for all.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, thank you to all those who have contributed to this very important report. Water is a basic prerequisite for life. The UN General Assembly declared clean water a human right in 2010 and the EU Citizens' Initiative on the subject gathered more than 1.8 million signatures. That is why we must strive to guarantee access to high-quality water at affordable prices for all citizens.  The purpose of the report is to update the Drinking Water Directive 1998 to reflect the present day. The updated directive harmonises drinking water quality standards so that they are based on the latest scientific data, in line with the recommendations of the World Health Organisation. The legislation will also be adapted to better respond to the challenges of climate change and the circular economy.  Water quality information should be transparent and easy to understand for citizens. This would also encourage water suppliers and national authorities to do their utmost to meet the water quality standards set out in the directive.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which We have impeccable drinking water in Europe. In an audit of data from 15 Member States in 2015, the Commission found that the compliance rate of microbiological and chemical parameters is 99%.  With our report, we are making a significant contribution to ensuring that this remains the case in the years to come, despite new challenges such as microplastics and drug residues. I very much welcome the fact that we are significantly expanding consumer information. We can be proud of our good tap water. Unfortunately, this has not always been the case with consumers.  However, it is also important to me that water suppliers can implement the directive in practice. Water supply varies widely between Member States. We must take this into account and must not put obstacles in the way of tried and tested forms of organisation, such as the supply of water in municipal hands.  With this in mind, I have tabled amendments on two issues for tomorrow's vote. Firstly, I would like to propose that the tried and tested system of measuring frequency, Annex II, Part B, be maintained. In accordance with the principle of proportionality, this allows for an exact adaptation of the measuring frequencies to the size of the water supplier. The amendments proposed by the Commission and the committee would lead to significant cost increases for some water suppliers, without any ultimately improvement in health protection. Secondly, I propose that the additional information requirements for large water suppliers in Annex IV be limited to information directly related to water quality. Information on energy and cost-efficiency is in the wrong place in this directive. I would be very, very grateful for consumer protection and the protection of the best forms of water supply organisations that have been tried and tested in the Member States, such as our municipal water suppliers.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the Commission on its proposal. This is not common, but I think it is an ambitious proposal, because indeed the revision of this directive must be ambitious to guarantee consumer protection. I would like to raise three points. First, water quality: it is essential to protect health and take into account all that is nitrate, drug residues, pesticides, endocrine disruptors, etc. But I would like to include the perfluorates - PFAS (polyfluoroalkyles and perfluoroalkyles) - as a whole, and not to distinguish, as you do, Mr Dantin, long and short chains. This is global because there is persistence and bioaccumulation. The second point is access to water, which for me is a fundamental human right. In the amendments, you say: 'Free water should be encouraged in restaurants and in administrations'. Rather than encouraging, access to water must be ensured, and it must be a right. And the third point is transparency. There has to be transparency, people have access ...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, through the 2014 Right2Water European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) nearly two million people across Europe sent a clear message to the EU that access to water is a human right. We did not choose this directive to respond to the demands of this petition, it was the Commission that came forward with this mediocre response. But what is more disappointing is that the European Parliament, which supposedly represents the people across the EU, is utterly failing those who signed that petition. In a shameful process of negotiations, Parliament has significantly weakened the provisions on access to water in this directive and this is an affront to the Right2Water petition and the petition procedure itself, which is the only channel for the people to directly voice their concern to the EU.  I was the rapporteur of the Right to Water Report that was approved by this Parliament in 2015. We endorsed the demands of the Right2Water petition and called for this human right to be enshrined in EU law. The European Economic and Social Committee also endorsed the petition’s commands. Now here we are, as the only directly elected EU institution, failing the nearly two million people who fought for this EU petition. You are treating ... (The President cut off the speaker by mistake, then allowed Ms Boylan to continue) There are two million people who want the human right to water to be enshrined in law and this speech is for them. I am elected by those people to represent their views. That is why other like-minded MEPs have submitted their alternative amendments and we will be bringing them tomorrow, and I hope that people will join the Right to Water outside Parliament at half nine in the morning as well.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I would like to apologise once again for making this mistake. It was not malice; please believe me!

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the vote on the drinking water directive offers us a unique opportunity to defend the right to water. Access to clean and safe drinking water for all must be guaranteed without distinction and not just mildly promoted as we are trying to do with this revision of the European Parliament. We of the 5 Star Movement have always brought this battle into the institutions, we are also doing it in Italy to promote public water as a common good. That is why we welcomed the European Commission's decision to finally respond to the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative and to do so for the first time through a legislative proposal. I would like this to be exactly the path to take for all the next ICE. Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we are defending everyone's health. Let us not forget and forget the 85 000 Venetians who are under health surveillance because of the contamination of Europe's second largest aquifer caused by PFAS, substances that are toxic and should never be in anyone's blood and that we can regulate tomorrow... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Clean drinking water is a human right, and that is right and proper. However, the Commission's proposal goes beyond the mark. I would like to explain this as follows: in my own country, Austria, drinking water meets the highest quality standards. The required amount of samples, of investigations, would mean seventy times the cost for two thirds of Austrian water suppliers, especially small suppliers. According to a study by the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences Vienna, the Commission proposal would lead to an average increase in costs from the current EUR 250 to EUR 18 00. The Commission would therefore be well advised to follow best practice examples, because Austrian water suppliers, with an average cost of EUR 250, manage to offer the highest quality standards. I therefore reject the Commission's proposal in this form. In the end, it would only threaten the small water cooperatives, help the large water cooperatives and ultimately only bring higher prices to consumers.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, both the Commission and the World Health Organisation, in their directives, invoice water on the basis of costs and the polluter pays principle. Private and local administrations are also provided as water bodies, i.e. butter on bread in the SYRIZA-ANEL government's plans for privatisations of EYDAP and EYATH and the full commercialisation of water. And the price limits proposed each time, the chemical exemptions, the derogations from the risk lists, the decade-long reductions, are linked to large business interests and competition. Workers will have to fight against the strategy of the European Union and governments, commercialisation and liberalisation, which in the name of profitability degrades water quality, burdening the popular family, strengthening the exploitation of workers in the sector.  We demand no form of direct or indirect privatisation, public water, free natural good, free from commercial use that requires a radically different path of development, water cheap and quality for all the people, no interruption of water in the poor grass roots.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, eighteen years ago we adopted the Water Framework Directive and, since then, the Member States have applied european Union rules quite rightly.  In the case of consumer waters, we need new quality parameters to update and improve current legislation; In addition, technical advances allow us better controls that should be implemented for the benefit of consumer public health.  Citizens' access conditions for water supply can and should also be improved, and the circular economy must be contributed by reducing facility losses.  I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague, Mr Dantin, on the because the work done in this report is complex and also very sensitive.
