With regard to voting, it is necessary to emphasize the efficiency of the measures to be taken: redundant or excessive obligations will only increase the price for citizens and greatly complicate the task for small suppliers, those who supply isolated areas and those with specific problems. The principle of cost integration of the Water Framework Directive requires us to be particularly careful when setting new parameters or sampling frequencies.  Citizens will appreciate it if we are able to combine improvements in water quality with containment of supply tariffs in a sector that already operates at a very good level.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the directive was the result of the initiative of over one million and 800 thousand European citizens who have called for the right to universal access to drinking water to be guaranteed: a right, a human right to be guaranteed, not just to be promoted.  We also want to defend a first but important result achieved with regard to PFAS, which is a strong endocrine disrupter. A very serious case of pollution by these substances has taken place in the Veneto region: almost 200 000 citizens now have a blood level hundreds of times higher than normal. For the first time, the Commission has introduced limits at European level, which we consider to be too high. Thanks to the compromise we proposed in envi committee, the total limit has been reduced by 40 %. We now hope that the Italian Government will also work at the European Council to improve what has already been achieved and to reach almost zero limits that I support. The directive also provides that individual Member States may set lower limits.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating access for all and everyone to drinking water, also under the European Citizens' Initiative Right2Water. I hope that the text that is to be voted on tomorrow will strongly change Rule 13, that it will not be limited to simple invitations but will set quality parameters for access and water quality. Today we are also here to support the reasons of the mothers "NO PFAS" of the Veneto region, mothers for whom water as a source of life has become a source of death. That is why we are calling for the tolerance level for the presence of these substances in water to be set to zero. We cannot accept the logic that puts economic profitability above people's health. European legislation obliges us to ensure that the precautionary principle prevails.  These substances and all their derivatives must be banned. Since they can't applaud from the audience, I applaud them from here.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, water is undoubtedly the most precious commodity on the planet. Without it, there's no life. But water quality is what it is all about. With the contamination of the environment by industry and the uncontrolled use of pesticides, it is a fact that the aquifer in many countries of the Union has been burdened with substances that make water dangerous. Access to good quality drinking water remains an important issue for European citizens, affecting their daily lives, health and activities. Member States are primarily responsible for meeting water quality standards, so that citizens have access to drinking water not just good but of high quality. Particular attention should be paid to the price of water and speculation should be avoided. I do not think that this revision has anything more to offer to water quality standards for human consumption, except that it should adapt the parametric values established to the latest scientific data. Clean and healthy water, therefore, for all citizens, enhancing transparency and consumer access to information and information on the quality of the water they consume.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Two million EU citizens do not have access to clean water. This is my heart: these are women, these are children, these are people in households who are to have this access in the future. I therefore think it is right that the European Commission has taken up the European citizens' initiative 'Right to Water' and has made a proposal. In detail, however, the proposal was, in my view and from our point of view, too centralised and too bureaucratic and not directed towards achieving its objectives. I am therefore pleased that a great deal has been achieved with hard work here in Parliament, particularly under the leadership of the rapporteur, Michel Dantin. Parliament has acted in a way like a sewage treatment plant for what has come from the Commission. The good has gone on, but in committee we were also able to improve a lot of things, to do a lot of good things and to omit many things that we did not think were good. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur for making this possible. Several state parliaments in my country and the Federal Council of the Austrian Parliament have also taken part in the parliamentary process.  Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Rapporteur Michel Dantin.  At the same time, however, I have to say that what has come out of the committee is not enough. There is still a double increase – a doubling – in the cost of quality control in the report, which is why we cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow is an important day in this Parliament. For the first time, a citizen initiative comes in the form of a legislative proposal by the Commission. And he comes to ask us to legislate on a basic good such as water. It asks us to adapt the quality of it to the knowledge we have today and to eliminate endocrine disruptors, among other substances harmful to health. It asks us to work together to mitigate climate change and make greater use of it directly and remove unnecessary plastics. But above all, he asks us to ensure universal access to health. Today, 11% of European citizens do not have access to quality drinking water. European citizenship , more than two million citizens - is repeatedly called for by the United Nations in different resolutions, and tomorrow the European Parliament cannot be below these claims or turn its back on European citizenship. And that is why it has to approve the amendments which will be tabled tomorrow. Let us therefore live up to this basic ambition of European citizenship.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Vella, my first thanks go to Mrs Dantin for the valuable work she has done in following up the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative, in which the Commission was asked to ensure that an essential asset such as water could flow from taps and could be of an appropriate quality for all European consumers and citizens. We want to strengthen consumer confidence and encourage the use of water coming out of our taps, but when setting parameters that increase water quality we must be careful not to overdo it and not to make water consumption impossible in some European areas. This is something that is likely to happen in the territory of my region, under the Volcano Etna, where volcanic soils are rich in boron and the boron parameter provided for in the Commission's proposal of one milligram per litre is a very low parameter. EFSA itself recommends a higher benchmark for the most susceptible categories of consumers; the World Health Organisation has a parameter of 2.4 times higher. That is why we have tabled an amendment that will allow water to be used in our regions as well, and that is why I call on you to vote for Amendment No 180. I agree with the idea of tightening up controls, of guaranteeing consumers, but we must not go beyond what the precautionary principle also requires of us.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We have twice as many speeches as we have planned to be able to process. That is why I intend to take only those speakers who have not yet spoken in any spontaneous speeches. Spontaneous speeches

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, in my one minute, I would just like to point out some of the important concepts that are associated with this report with this legislation. First, it is accessibility – if water is truly available to all citizens – and to prevent speculation about the availability of water. Secondly, it is quality, it is not only about clean water, but also, of course, it is also about water that is free from, for example, endocrine disruptors. Or, for example, the issue of microplastics. Next, it is sustainability, the ability to supply this available water to citizens, but also the sustainability of the whole system. This means that the system should be able to respond to new technologies, while ensuring that the available water does not dramatically increase household costs. Another is transparency, i.e. predictability of the water supply system and predictability of water quality as such. The last one for me is a partnership project, i.e. partnerships with municipalities and towns. At the same time, I would like to point out that in the Czech Republic we have, for example, many citizens who unfortunately do not yet have available water. They are one of the 11% of the European population.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, drinking water as a human right does sound responsible and noble. But we need significant resources and a quality legislative framework to ensure this. The objective of this Directive is to protect human health from the negative effects of water pollution and to foster universal access to water intended for human consumption and, in this regard, it is a step in the right direction. Universal access guarantee requires that the conditions for quality water distributions be met at the same time.  I welcome the commitment to the principle of subsidiarity and recognition of competences for Member States in applying minimum quality requirements. With this proposal, Member States are given greater freedom, but also responsibility for assessing risks to human health. It is important that all members stick to the agreement so that European citizens actually have access to quality water.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Today we are discussing everyone's right to clean water. Without water no life. But how do we actually treat our most important asset, our drinking water? Real safety is about access to clean water, clean air and food free of toxins. Yet we allow strong interests to poison our drinking water. In northern Europe's largest drinking water supply, Vättern, our defenses practice sniping. This means that large quantities of toxic waste in the form of ammunition disappear straight into the water that actually supplies more than a quarter of a million people with drinking water. Climate change also means that more Europeans are likely to want to take their water from this drinking water source, Vättern. It is time to prioritise drinking water as one of the most important safety issues. Vättern's water should become a national matter. Over the next few years, we must invest heavily in our water treatment plants so that drug residues, microplastics and other toxins and chemicals are purified.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to water and sanitation was recognised as a human right at the UN eight years ago. In this context, we must not forget that Member States are obliged to put in place action plans aimed at ensuring universal and equal access to safe and affordable drinking water for all by 2030. But how do we want to prove this when we are seeing insufficient investment in the maintenance and restoration of water infrastructure? How does the state want to ensure that access to clean drinking water is not restricted due to unavailability, when water management is constantly threatened with privatization and is already privatized in many states? How do we want to provide citizens with healthy, harmless water if the Commission does not present an updated EU strategy on endocrine disruptors? If we want to prove to citizens that their areas of interest are a priority for us, we need to start from the ground up. The foundation is water for me, so we have to start with the right to drinking water.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the need for access to high-quality drinking water is a vital need and a right of every human being to survive. In this day and age, meeting this need is of particular importance because we must face the consequences of climate change, but also the contamination of the aquifer and water sources by industrial waste. In order to be able to deal with all these problems, water sources must be checked and managed by the competent authorities of the Member States, because they have the potential to protect both sources and, above all, to take measures to ensure that they are not contaminated. The state also has the ability to secure cheap water and access to all the social class in the country and not let it be controlled by private companies.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So, the European Citizens' Initiative Right to Water was signed by almost 1.9 million European citizens, who also requested universal access to water in European law.  But not any water, but clean water, no microplastics, no hormonal disruptors, no other harmful substances in the water. Therefore, of course, appropriate monitoring is also needed.  But this proposal, which we will be addressing tomorrow, is not ambitious enough in some part and does not guarantee, as an obligation, universal access to clean water. That is why tomorrow we must insist on maintaining strong provisions.  Let it, of course, be what we have in my country, the Republic of Slovenia, to encourage you, and that is to include in our Constitution the right to clean drinking water as a human right, and this may be a good example for this House as well.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I very much welcome the messages from the Parliament confirming that everybody agrees that the EU should respond and act in the interest of our citizens and that everybody supports the Sustainable Development Goal 6 and better access to water. I am hoping to see this reflected in the results of the vote tomorrow so that Parliament comes to trilogues with an ambitious position when it comes to health protection and access to water. As you know, this proposal has been highlighted by President Juncker in his letter of intent to President Tajani and Chancellor Kurz as a key initiative for adoption before the European elections next year, contributing to the first priority of the agenda for jobs growth, fairness and democratic change agreed in July 2014. I would like to reiterate that the Commission stands ready to help the co-legislators reach an agreement that will support the objectives we all share and will ensure that our citizens benefit from the highest health protection for decades to come. I wish you success for the vote tomorrow and thank you once again for your commitment to this fight.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank each and every one of those who has intervened in this debate and bring some thoughts. I do not know if we represent a million, two million or 500 million of our fellow citizens, but what I am sure of is that the vast majority of European citizens are asking us for access to water for all, which requires cost control, control of expenses, to enable everyone to consume so much water, and good quality water. , that he wants. Many observations have been made on chemical data. I would not want to get into some kind of shallot race. Science is science. Today, however, there is no harmonized measurement standard for, for example, microplastics. The proposal before you introduces it. We know that endocrine disruptors have an influence on the environment. WHO tells us that today it is not in a position to measure its exact impact on health, which is why we have proposed a fine follow-up, pending the evolution of knowledge. I believe that the health of our fellow citizens does not belong to one or the other. The health of our citizens is our collective responsibility and it deserves no outbids or discounts. That's the meaning of our common struggle. Water quality is one of the first elements of public health in Europe. Having an excellent level of water quality for as many people as possible, and on the shortest possible horizon, for all, is the assurance of good health for our fellow citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The Drinking Water Directive is one of europe's regulatory pillars in the water sector. Introduced at the end of the 1980s, it needs - after more than 20 years - a review aimed at aligning drinking water quality standards with the most up-to-date scientific data and adapting the legislative framework to better respond to new challenges, such as climate change and the transition to a circular economy. This is the first time that European legislation has taken on board the demands for a European citizens' initiative, which in reality went even further than the position reached in the ENVI Committee. For this reason, I supported the tabling of a number of amendments to support the objective of providing universal access to water. The Member States must take all the necessary measures to ensure universal access to water, which I consider to be a fundamental right. The revision of the Drinking Water Directive is an excellent opportunity to finally incorporate this right into legislation and to demonstrate that the European Union is capable of affecting concrete issues of the daily lives of European citizens. I agree with and support all the amendments aimed at reducing or eliminating PFAS levels in drinking water.

text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Frédérique Ries on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment (COM(2018)0340 – C8-0218/2018 – 2018/0172(COD)) (A8-0317/2018).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen, this is beginning as a beautiful story. In the mid-1950s, plastic, invented a century earlier, was a revolution. An invention that changed everything, it must be said, that changed the products, that changed the quantities and that changed mainly our behaviors, with the advent of the all-disposable. Today, this story is turning into a nightmare: 8 billion tons produced in less than 65 years for 6 billion tons of waste. The figures are staggering: more than 400,000 tonnes a year for Europe alone. Everywhere, the oceans have become our last garbage can and they are dying of it. The images loop around all the media: our beaches disfigured by waste, cormorants smothered by plastic bags, sea turtles whose stomachs are colonized by pieces of plastic ... These images are unbearable. The Commission therefore proposes to cover the ten disposable plastic objects that are most often found on our beaches, plus fishing equipment, which together accounts for 70% of marine waste. And the 51 Members of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety who supported my report in the vote have a realistic objective - I want to stress this - which is to ban this single-use plastic when a sustainable alternative exists, such as paper, bamboo, glass, corn starch, etc. At the same time, it will stimulate innovation and create jobs in Europe. The Commission goes so far as to talk about 50,000 jobs. It is also a matter of putting in place a series of progressive measures, an obligation, especially for producers, to take responsibility, labelling certain products that are difficult to recycle, awareness campaigns and, of course, ambitious measures to reduce the consumption of certain items. As rapporteur, I have wished, together with the shadow rapporteurs, that I will not all name here but whom I would like to thank very sincerely for the excellence of our cooperation, so we wish to raise the level of ambition of the Commission's proposal. To this end, we have added three products to the original list of prohibitions - this one is known - cotton rods, straws, plates, cutlery, touillettes. In this case, we add expanded polystyrene packaging, which is found in fast food, oxdegradable bags, which fragment under the influence of light and therefore contribute to marine pollution, as well as ultralight bags, i.e. bags of less than 15 microns, while maintaining a derogation mainly for reasons of hygiene. And I will make a small comment on this: I clearly do not have the same reading line as some colleagues who, through deletions, derogations, attack the very heart of our text and try to save plates or cutlery made in southern Italy, or German balloons. I would like to make it clear that the text does not provide for a ban on balloons and, as I have read today, to address the pleasure of children. This type of argument is Euroscepticism. It is not in the text, and I come back to that text. Where we have not banned, we propose a robust legal framework, a timetable to reduce the consumption of food containers and cups; the EPP is tabling a plenary amendment here to immediately reduce consumption of these two products by 25%, to which I fully agree. The signal sent to the Member States is the right one. On the other hand, I am opposed to Amendment 122, which exempts SMEs completely until 2023 and paves the way, it is obvious, for all abuses and legal optimisations. With regard to plastic bottles, we are adding, to the 90% separate collection target, a target of collecting 35% recycled content by 2025, some industry champions are already there. For fishing devices, nets, ropes, etc., which are responsible for 27% of marine pollution, this is a priority. I reinforce the Commission's text by drawing on the best practices that come to us from Norway and Iceland, experts, if any. The Commission on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has also followed me in my willingness to take into account the fight against the environmental damage of tobacco. I am obviously targeting the plastic filters of cigarettes, it is cellulose acetate. An ambitious reduction target: minus 50% by 2025, minus 80% by 2030, and we finally confirm the responsibility of producers under the polluter pays principle. I conclude, Mr President, that citizens expect us to adopt the most ambitious legislation against single-use plastics on Wednesday. It is now, ladies and gentlemen, and it is up to us to make this choice for the environment, for the generations that follow us and also for those millions, those tens of millions of Europeans who are mobilised, who are watching us and who are ready to consume differently.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Ms Ries, and all the shadow rapporteurs for proceeding with this report very quickly and with a lot of ambition. Urgency and ambition are indeed necessary because we are facing a huge environmental challenge. Plastic parts are found in sea turtles, seals, birds, whales and fish. They enter the food chain, harm the environment and pose a threat to human health. We have all heard the estimate that there will be more plastic than fish in the ocean by 2050. Every minute, the equivalent of one garbage truck filled with plastic is being dumped into the ocean. Due to the increase in consumption and production, this number is projected to rise substantially. Thankfully, although these quantities of plastic and their impact on the marine environment are shocking, just 10 single-use items, along with abandoned and lost fishing gear, represent a great majority of the source of the problem and that is about 70% in all.  That allowed the Commission, in the directive we tabled in May, to focus directly on the cause of the problem. In the plastics strategy, we made it clear that we do not demonise plastic – it is an adaptable and useful material – but we promised to table a proposal that would tackle marine litter effectively in response to mounting scientific evidence and mounting public outcry. The directive aims at banning certain single-use plastic products where alternatives are readily available and affordable, as is the case for cotton bud sticks, balloon sticks, cutlery, plates, straws and stirrers. Where there is no real alternative material to plastic, the directive’s goal is to significantly reduce the use. This will apply to cups and lids, food containers and very light carrier bags. The directive also proposes obligations for producers of tobacco product filters, drink bottles, crisp packets, wet wipes, drink cups and lids, food containers, balloons and very lightweight carrier bags to help cover the costs of waste management and clean-up. We propose a 90% separate collection rate for single-use plastic bottles by 2025. This will positively influence the quality of collected material, making recycling more profitable and making cheaper and better quality recycled plastic available for new products. Clear and standardised labelling will be required on sanitary towels, wet wipes and balloons, as they get into our seas and oceans because people do not know how to dispose of them or they are unaware of the negative impact of the products.  Fishing gear represents around 27% of all beach litter. Here, producers will be required to cover the costs of fishing-gear-related waste collection from port reception facilities, its transport and treatment. Some of the amendments tabled recently in this House could very significantly reduce the scope of the directive and jeopardise the achievement of its objective. This would not be to the benefit of our citizens. I hope that on Wednesday this Parliament will give a strong mandate to Ms Ries which will include no further derogations.  As highlighted by President Juncker in his State of the Union speech ‘citizens have high expectations for this initiative and we, as European institutions, have to meet those expectations.’ This is why I am looking forward to starting negotiations in order to ensure a first-reading agreement during the Austrian Presidency so that this legislation can make a real difference on the ground as soon as possible.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the European Commission for its rather ambitious proposal. We need a strong legal basis for action to reduce plastic pollution. As the rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I would like to emphasise that, in order to ensure a greater reduction in plastic consumption, we must also pay greater attention to plastic pollution in agriculture, even if this impact on the aquatic environment is indirect. We must therefore set targets in the directive for reducing the pollution of microplastics in soil, and we need to take additional precautions to discount the use of biodegradable plastic. We must also ensure that the achievement of the objectives of the directive does not become a burden on our businesses, farmers and consumers. Finally, in order to ensure that our ambitions do not become merely declarations, we need to achieve that all Member States have specific targets to reduce the consumption of single-use plastic products.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Rapporteur for the PECH Committee. – Mr President, dear Commissioner and dear friend, plastic is one of the great innovations of the 20th century with significant impacts on the economy and daily life of all of us. On the other hand, it has disastrous impacts on the environment, biodiversity, the health of ecosystems and, however absurd and contradictory it may seem, on the quality of daily life. It is regrettable that we have let plastics expand and we are only now really starting to produce governance tools to correct the management errors of the last seventy years.  May it serve as a warning to us not to neglect the guard and caution for management and governance for current and future technological innovations.  Fisheries account for 27% of single-use plastics occurring at sea. It is therefore very important to align this proposal with the Waste Reception Directive in port areas. The plastics directive only sins for the delay and I hope that an ambitious document will be obtained on Wednesday.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his Thank you for presenting us with the report. We waited a little bit for it, but now he was there. Thank you, too, Mrs Ries, for working very well and swiftly on this report. I can confirm that this was a joy for all of us. We have heard how many hundreds of thousands of tonnes of waste are in the seas. We know how many hundreds of millions of euros of losses are missing from the economies, and that is why the ten or now twelve points that we have listed are just right. I strongly support that. However, I would very much like to make a point which is very important to me, because I have been reporting waste in this House for over 25 years and I have the stupid peculiarity of always looking at what is actually happening with these reports in recent years. And sometimes breakfast doesn't taste good in the morning, when you see how few successes we've had. You can deny that, but I would oppose it. I will tell you one thing: it is very important that in this report we have cooperation with industry, with recyclers and with consumers. If the industry does not finally understand that it has to make contact with the recyclers, how to develop a product that can be taken apart afterwards, if this awareness does not take up slowly but surely, we will not achieve the recycling targets. If we write them down, that is not enough. We have to develop motivation, we have to get the middle class to do it. I am not at all concerned with discrediting plastic, not at all, quite the contrary! However, I would like what the producers put together to be eventually separated by other industries and then recycled. Mr President, if we do not do that, your grandchildren and my grandchildren will one day have real problems with the procurement of raw materials. Commissioner, that you are working on it was right and proper, thank you very much.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must also move towards plastic with great ambition. Our courage and determination have been fundamental to achieving the Paris Agreement and can also be so for single-use plastics. In recent days, Japan, which did not sign the Charter for Plastic in the Oceans at the G7 in July, has announced first and courageous measures to reduce consumption. That is why we were right in the ENVI Committee to make the directive more ambitious, we did so in a sustainable and reasonable way. With the vote in this House in Strasbourg, we can take five important steps forward: to take measures that are useful for our oceans; take an important step forward to stem an unsustainable culture of waste and disposable use; support innovation and scientific research to create new jobs by developing eco-sustainable production; strengthening the extended responsibility of the producer in accordance with the 'polluter pays' principle; to give more information to our citizens; do more recycling.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, plastic is a valuable material, but we are so sloppy about it. Disposable plastic ends up massively in nature and the environment, outside it, along the street side, in the verges, in the ditches and rivers and finally in our seas, resulting in the well-known plastic soup. Indeed, if no action is taken, Commissioner, by 2050 there will be more plastic swimming in our seas than fish. So the rudder has to change. We must make full commitment to sustainable and responsible management of plastic throughout the value chain. We had already agreed on this last month, when we overwhelmingly approved my initiative report here. This week we have the opportunity to put the action to the floor and to approve this proposal. And for me, the following three points are essential: One, there will be a tailor-made approach. Not all products are shaved over the same comb. Two, the producers have to pay for the clean-up of plastic litter, including cigarette butts. Three single-use plastic drink bottles must contain 35% recycled plastic by 2025 and 90% must be collected separately. I understand that the focus is first on those products that are most commonly found on our European beaches, but for me an overall strategy for disposable products remains a necessary next step. All that remains is to thank Mr Ries and my shadow rapporteurs. The compromise we have reached is balanced and I will support it to the maximum.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all we have to ask what we actually want. We want to get rid of microplastics and nanoplastics, we want to get rid of plastic rafts that are in the world's seas, we want to get rid of plastic debris that pollutes our beaches all over the world. I remember very vividly, as Mrs Ries also pointed out at this early stage, our journey of discovery in my childhood in the Finnish archipelago. That's when we found a variety of exciting treasures on the beaches. They were usually wooden boxes, from which imagination was used to wonder if they were left behind by some Robert Louis Stevenson pirate. They were useful wooden objects, at least for a young man. Today, if I go on a journey of discovery with my granddaughter, there are no such exciting and interesting discoveries on our shores. There are a variety of pretty disgusting plastic objects that don't help children's imaginations.  But at the same time as we are happy to see that the Commission has taken off on this issue, we need an overall survey of what kind of plastics we use, where they are useful, where they can be replaced, where they cannot be replaced, where they are harmful. With such an overall survey alone, we will be able to tackle all these challenges in a sensible way.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! The fight against plastic pollution both in the sea and in nature has become a public matter, which is why it is important that we now deliver something properly so that the people - our citizens - can see that we are doing something right here. I would therefore like to thank the Commission for a good proposal that goes for the strategy we also had in my plastic bag law, namely prevention. That's the most important thing of all: prevention!  I would also like to thank Mr Frédérique Ries for an excellent report, which has been further improved. I hope that it will be adopted fairly unchanged. A small remark, especially to my Italian colleagues, who obviously believe that saving Italian industry is more important than nature, and who believe that plastics can be replaced with bioplastics: bioplastics are as polluting in nature, they do not break down in the sea, and it should be used with as much caution as regular plastics are used.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we’ve all been horrified by the images of plastics in our ocean and we’re becoming more aware of the consequences of our throw—away economy. We are now in a position as legislators to put in place aggressively ambitious rules to stop this plastics crisis and not just replace them with biodegradables. Whatʼs great is that the people are behind us on this one. This is a crucially important vote, and people are interested and they want a strong response. We need to get this directive right from the very start and lay out a firm framework, but we are setting ourselves up for failure with the current definition of single—use plastic. It must be rock solid, with no loopholes for industry to exploit. Also, Member States need to be able to be more ambitious than this directive. If they wish to forge ahead with more ambitious ideas, this directive should not hold them back. The efficiency of the Single Market cannot be prioritised over the environment. This is our chance. Let’s be ambitious on plastics.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this proposed directive typifies why we need a Brexit. Our UK Environment Agency has published a life cycle assessment, which demonstrates that oxo-biodegradable plastic is superior to bio-plastic. This was reinforced by the Intertek report of 2012. The EU has instigated its own technical study but want to rush legislation through before the findings are published. This indicates that the European Union are trying very hard to airbrush oxo-biodegradable plastic out of the discussion entirely. Why? Because this is being developed by a British company, whilst the competitor technology is in the hands of the Italian company Novamont, who have received direct support from the Italian Government, who in turn have made it mandatory for retailers to use Novamont’s product. The Italian product will not fully degrade in the open air, whilst the British product does so. The Italian product cannot be recycled, whilst the British product can be, if required. The Italian process produces far more CO2, indicating that more energy is required to manufacture it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Frédérique RIES
text: 'blue card' question. Mr President, I am no longer sure, I have 30 seconds, right? I'll go quickly then. With regard to biodegradable plastics, I have here a UN report, the title of "Biodegradable plastics, a false solution to marine pollution" - this is a UN study. Plastics labelled as biodegradable do not degrade easily or quickly in the oceans, most plastics labelled as organic will decompose only from a certain temperature, 50 degrees at least, which will never be reached in the depths of an ocean ...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Ries, you have been in Parliament for quite some time. You should know that the blue card is not there to make another statement. That was not a question for Mr Agnew. Mr Agnew, I would nevertheless like to give you the opportunity to reply if you wish.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, as you said, it wasn’t a question, but I noticed that the speaker didn’t use the word ‘oxo-biodegradable’ plastic. This is different to ‘bioplastic’, and this is where a lot of confusion has arisen.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, since the 1950s, eight billion tonnes of plastic have been produced and less than 10% have been recycled. With time from the century to the millennium to degrade, and exponential use in our societies, this plastic waste is ubiquitous, especially in our oceans and in our atmosphere. With the second largest maritime area in the world, France is particularly hard hit. Recycling is necessary but insufficient, since the production of recycled plastic requires the introduction of new plastic, contributing to the permanent increase in waste. Similarly, some so-called "biodegradable" plastics do not disappear. Plastic breaks down into microparticles or endocrine disruptors that are found absolutely everywhere. Water, food, but also atmosphere, toys, floors, furniture, makeup, everything goes there. In short, dramatic consequences on health and especially in the early stages of life, where our hormones play as important a role as genes in physiological development. Here, the impacts can be irreversible for our children. The only solution is to limit these plastic products wherever substitutes exist and then ban them from being put on the market, and we must finally consider reducing consumption for others.  France and Europe must be at the forefront of this transition.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We have a huge problem with plastic in the sea. That is why it is good that the European Commission has presented the proposal, and it is also good that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has sharpened it a little further. I would ask colleagues to support an amendment tabled by the PPE-DE, where we are making it a little clearer. According to the Commission's proposal, there are reduction targets for some products, but it is not clear how high they should be. In the worst-case scenario, a Member State could say: one or two per cent. And that is probably not the solution to the problem. That is why a minimum number must be in place. Everything about this is very welcome. However, I would also ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to support two amendments tabled by the PPE-DE which remove a product from the legal framework, namely balloons. I believe that we are doing ourselves a disservice if we start to regulate this now. It could be a symbol of over-bureaucratization. According to Science, we have eight million tonnes of plastic marine pollution per year, five kilos of which come from balloons from the European Union. I don't think emotionally we're going to get through that. In the constituency of Karl-Heinz Florenz – as it was said today in the German media – a little boy had a balloon lifted to send a picture to his late grandfather. Do we really want to avoid this? Do we want to have stickers or other markings? I don't think we're doing that. We are tackling the problem, but we are not exaggerating it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Blue card question. Mr President! Two municipalities in Denmark have tried to ban hot air balloons coming flying from England because they are being used as advertising. They're carried in with the westerly wind. I know that coastal areas are not the great scourge of Germany, but there have therefore been large areas of Denmark where they come in windy, and of course you can say that the responsibility of producers is already clear because you can see that they have been used for advertising. But it's actually a strain on these coastal beaches, and I can...

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mrs Auken. You, too, have been in business long enough to know that this was not a question. At least for the sake of decency, one could have asked. Mr Liese is familiar to you. Incidentally, it should be known that I am not knocking big on the blue cards, where there are strict speaking times – thirty seconds – but I am immediately taking the floor. Mr Liese, although that was not a question, I would nevertheless like to give you the opportunity to react.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The example of Margrete Auken shows that the Commission's proposal is bad and that Amendments Nos 125 and 126 must be supported. The Commission is seriously proposing that the release of balloons and the whole issue of balloons should only be regulated by the EU if private individuals do – at children's birthdayparties and at weddings. If this is done for commercial purposes – by industry, by the advertising industry – it is allowed. That cannot be true.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Immaġina xi tkun ir-reazzjoni kieku tisma' li hawk minuta fl-istess post hemm trakk taż-żibel mimli plastic jisvojta l-iskart fl-ibħra tagħna. Imma fir-realtà dak huwa li qiegħed jiġri bħalissa. Dan huwa l-mument li l-kuxjenza ambjentali fost i大-大ittadini tagħna dwar kif nistgħu niddisponu aħjar mill-iskart tal-plastic qiegħda hemmhekk. L-ebda pajjiż waħdu ma jista' jagħmel id-differenza, imma magħqudin flimkien, b'policies komuni bejnietna, nistgħu verament nibdew innaqsu l-plastiks li jintużaw darba u li għhomali hemm alternattivi oħra. Issa ppermettuli niffoka fuq il-Baħar Mediterranju wara li rapport maħruġ riħrument identifika l-Mediterran bħala il-baħar li fih livell record ta' tniġġis minn microplatks li qegħdin jheddu l-ispeħi marittimi u anki s-saħħa-tal bdemnie. Illum il-ġurnata, il-plastic jirrappreżenta ħamsa u disgħin fil-mija tal-iskart li hemm fil-wi大大 tal-Mediterran u l-bajjiet li għandna. Fl-Ewropa nipproduikeu ammont kbir ta' skart tal-plastic li ħafna minnu jispi大a fil-miżbliet u miljuni ta' tunnellati minn dan il-plastic qed jispi大a proprju fil-Mediterran.  I nistgħux inħallu li l-Mediterran ikompli jifga fil-plastic. Irridu naġixxu issa biex verament insalvaw l-ibħra tagħna, huma fejn huma. Din il-liġi, illi se nivvutaw fuqha din il-ġimgħa, hija l-ewwel pass, però jien irrid nara ftehim legali internazzjonali li jwassal biex ma jibqax jintrema plastic fl-ibħra tagħna. Irid ikollna targets b'saħħithom biex il-plastik kollu eventwalment jiġi rri大iklat.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we are facing a huge problem whose exact dimensions we do not even know the exact dimensions or the consequences of: we are discovering them a little at a time with studies. We know that nanoplastics enter our organism, we know that microplastics enter the food chain and the number of species in which these microplastics are detected is increasing more and more every day. A few days ago, the study analysed samples of sea salt, cooking salt that we use in our kitchens: 92 % of this salt contains microplastics. The Commission has made an interesting and very good proposal. , without seeking derogations and without looking for loopholes. That is what we need, because the citizens want an effective and concrete response.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that we cannot vote no, that we must necessarily support this directive, because in any case it will make it possible to significantly reduce the production of plastic waste, we would miss it. However, 46 billion plastic bottles are produced every year in the European Union, and since it takes about four hundred years to dispose of this plastic, it is easy to calculate that in twenty years a billion plastic bottles will be produced and accumulated. We all know that all this plastic goes into the food chain, so we eat and drink plastic every day. In the face of this scandal, we have unfortunately not been able to impose binding targets that permanently reduce plastic bottles. We honestly believe that for lack of courage today we are wasting a unique opportunity, a historic opportunity to save our planet.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how can you say that Europe is represented here? It's a disgrace. 95 % of plastic pollution in the seas comes from Asia and Africa, the problem is solved by intervening there. The economic crisis is continuing, you are forcing us into austerity policies, but no one is touching the French deficit or the German surplus and your priority is to ban balloon sticks and plastic plates under the pretext of saving the environment? Why did Vice-President Timmermans put so much pressure on this dossier? Such an important subject would have required a more in-depth analysis. This is crap, you're out of reality! Plastic must be collected and recycled, not banned, and it is not yet possible to replace it. Have you rightly reduced the use of paper with the obligation of digital, and then forced the use of paper for plates and glasses? But what's the point? Do you do it for your northern European companies? The only companies that will really be affected are the Italian ones, whose quality you cannot beat, and then resort to these means. This is an attack on Italy at a time when we are finally raising our heads in Europe! Vice-President Timmermans, Commissioner Moscovici, look at the data! You don't have the slightest... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Lancini. If I may say that it is highly advisable to listen to the interpreters from time to time, when you see the interpreters fighting.  You have not been given more than a minute's speaking time by your group. It doesn't help if you write it all down and rattle down a speech. This may be of interest to the Italians, but the rest of the continent loses such a word. That is a great pity, sir, although I do not necessarily share everything you have said. I am not giving you the floor. I have tried several times to teach some colleagues that they are working here at an appropriate pace of speech. It would be good if someone would follow it occasionally. Mrs Ries, it is part of my policy here, when I am in the Chair, that I do not reward colleagues from whom I have taken the floor – which I did with Mr Lancini because he spoke not only too quickly, but also for too long – by allowing a blue card.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Mr President, plastic has become a fundamental material for our human life. We have probably abused its use and lacked adequate awareness and management by producers, managers and consumers. The result is the dumping of plastic waste on the high seas with images that we have all seen. We share with the Commission the objective of reducing plastic waste at sea, as well as the concern about its decomposition into microplastics.  In recent years there has been considerable advances in the chemical and materials industry, so we have new types of biodegradable and compostable plastics that allow safer applications and packaging than the previous ones, especially in the food field.  This allows us to have substitute products to ask that prohibitions should only be established in the case of lack of alternatives. In most cases, reduction targets, design requirements, management or reporting obligations can also be established.  I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Ries, on her report, even if we do not fully agree with my group. And I would like to conclude by saying that if we want to protect the seas, we need to address the problem at the international level. As with other environmental issues, the European Union alone cannot solve the problem. We also need consumer environmental education and its collaboration.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, reducing the impact of plastics on the environment and in the seas is an absolute urgency in the light of the worrying data on this subject. As rapporteur for my group in the AGRI Committee, I have made, in addition to the desire to consider plastics that pollute the soil, the request for a precise assessment of many outstanding issues in the directive: the alternatives to be used, the replacement times, the impact on prices if we talk about products from agricultural crops, the impact that they will have on the employment front in the absence of forward-looking measures in this regard. Unfortunately, the directive is not sufficiently incisive, sometimes it generalises where a distinction has to be made and in other cases it is too timid, it does not consider closed systems where recycling is efficient, it does not distinguish biodegradable plastics from others, and they are just a few examples. So let us be honest. Greater courage on the part of some groups would have led to corrective measures and better able to reconcile economic and environmental sustainability, both shared goods and to be defended.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commission for this proposal, because it’s quite a U-turn, isn’t it? When, in 2014, this Commission started, it wanted to stop the regulation on reducing single—use plastic carrier bags, which our Green rapporteur, Ms Auken, has strengthened in order to get reduction targets. This Commission started, with better regulation against red tape, etc., to try to stop this proposal. But itʼs thanks to our Green rapporteur that we got this proposal on the table, and it’s now a success of implementation. So I think that the Commission has learned – and now finally also understood – that we can do more against plastic pollution to really go against single—use plastic: banning the plastic that is ending up on our beaches, making sure that we are reducing where possible, and also extending the producers’ responsibility. This shows that we can have a Commission that delivers for people and the environment, and I do hope that this Commission will continue that and stop this nonsense about red tape.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I was pleased to have the opportunity to work on this legislation as PPE shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Fisheries. This is hugely important from a fisheries point of view, not only because it will help to clean up the seas and coastal areas that are vital for our fishing communities, but also because it seeks to deal with the huge amount of waste from used fishing gear that is often discarded into the sea.  Global production of plastics has increased 20—fold since the 1960s and had reached 322 million tonnes worldwide by 2015. In the EU alone, around 26 million tonnes of plastic waste is generated every year and less than 30% of it is recycled. If you combine the production process of plastics and their incineration after use, the amount of carbon being put into the atmosphere globally as a result of plastics is around 400 million tonnes. This is enormous. If we want to have any chance of meeting our 2°C target, we need to vastly reduce emissions from sectors and sources where emissions are so avoidable. I strongly welcome the work of my colleagues on this file. Of the litter found on our beaches in Europe, 84% is made up of plastic with 50% being single—use plastics. Unrecycled plastic takes hundreds of years to break down and much can’t even be recycled. Our choice, therefore, is to follow what the Commission is saying and restrict single—use plastics.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the difficult work she has done in seeking a lowest common denominator. I would like to start by saying that I agree with the objectives of the proposal: the problem is there and it is clear to everyone, but we must have a balanced approach to protecting the environment, the seas and the oceans, but also being careful to initiate a gradual and feasible economic transition, both for producers and for our citizens in their dual capacity as consumers but also as workers in the sector. Plastic is an important material that should not be demonised but whose use must be progressively and constantly reduced. However, we need balance in this measure and one thing I asked for , and that is why I tabled corrective amendments, was not to extend, with regard to ultralight plastic bags, the list of prohibitions and bans provided for in the proposal. As Mrs Auken, who was rapporteur and I committee chairman, will recall, after a very difficult trialogue we managed in 2015 to bring the plastic bags directive to a successful end. And now to think that we have oriented technologies in one direction and two years after that directive we are changing course with the ban ... It seems to me too early, we need to provide for a gradual exit and reduction targets, not a ban. I do not believe that this is the right way to act in Europe.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Ries and Commissioner Vella for their constructive work. In order to prevent Moby Dick from becoming Moby Sick, we have to act now. More than half of the plastics we find on our beaches are single-use plastics. Even the degraded plastics, or microplastics, are fatal to many marine species, which die after the worst possible sufferings. 87% of EU citizens are deeply concerned by the effects of plastics on our environment, and I have to tell you that they are right. But the simple banning of certain single-use plastics is not enough. In the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I tabled an amendment for a binding reduction target of 50% for single-use plastics in all Member States by 2025. Unfortunately, this was too ambitious for some Members of this Parliament. But we owe it to our citizens to stand strong, and thatʼs why we have tabled another proposal for binding national targets in plenary. I note that the rapporteur supports this amendment, and I hope that others will find the courage to do so as well.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Hansen. I happened to notice that you had recently moved on. I would like to congratulate you very warmly on your first speech in Parliament.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, the European Union produces as much as 26 million tonnes of plastic waste a year. It is a huge waste, both for the environment and for the economy. It is estimated that we lose up to EUR 100 billion a year in value because plastics are thrown away.  It is quite a radical proposal from the Commission to ban certain single-use plastics altogether from 2021. But it is a sensible line, because there are already more sustainable replacements for these objects, so they can easily be abandoned. It also accelerates product development, which allows us to get sustainable, better, more environmentally friendly products. I therefore support the Commission's proposal for a total ban on certain single-use plastics. In addition, it is important that we otherwise strive to reduce unnecessary plastic waste. Among other things, the proposal that all Member States should organise collection for plastic bottles is to be supported. In my own country, Finland, there has been a bottle deposit system that has been operating for decades, which allows more than 90% of plastic bottles to be returned and re-recycled and do not end up on beaches. We know that it takes up to 400 years for a plastic bottle to break up in the sea.  But one mistake has remained with the Commission's proposal, and that is that disposable mugs with low plastic content could also be banned on the basis of this directive. We need to make a change to this, because we know that cardboard plastic cups are very environmentally friendly, but they require a small amount of plastic to keep the liquid inside them. That is something we need to rectify in this House.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are talking about pollution in the oceans and the first thing that comes to mind is drifting plastic. Plastics are a visible problem that we can no longer ignore, especially the accumulation in our oceans and on our beaches that is preventable. The presence of the disposable due to its ease of use led to the unnecessary use of the use of this type of products. Consumption must be more sustainable and is more consumer-conscious, for the preference for reusable materials, for the correct way to eliminate waste and for the extreme need for the use of disposables that have an option for biodegradable materials safely in the aquatic environment. I therefore believe that the measures we will adopt will prevent the situation from worsening in the future, but they will not put out in the blink of an eye the problem we have around the world today. We must find sustainable solutions, including by investing in the cleanliness of the oceans by collecting and routing waste. The place of plastic is not in the environment, nor in the landfill. Fulfilling the circulation of the economy and removing the proper value of this waste to reduce its environmental footprint is essential. In the end, the rest of the world will follow our example.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think the debate has shown that plastic waste really is a huge risk to the environment. They create a problem for human health, they pollute our seas, which are now full of plastics, they undermine all marine wealth and this, of course, is something that worries all of us, especially us, since in Greece we have clean seas and we want to have clean seas in the future, since tourism is a huge industry for our country. It is therefore logical to set the objective of banning specific disposable plastics with specific actions taken. In particular, our farmers should not be protected because there is contamination of the aquifer by plastics. The transition must, of course, be gradual, weighted, and balance our interventions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, there is no doubt that we live in the plastics century. There are currently 6 billion tonnes of plastic waste, which pollute the seas and the aquifer. If this ocean pollution continues, by 2050 there will be more plastics in the seas than fish and mammals. This development is of particular concern to coastal states, one of which is Greece, and we must also focus on the fact that we are facing a difficult situation. States should invent new materials that are recyclable and, in the event that these alternative materials do not exist, the use of plastics should be restricted. Strict fines should also be imposed on those who pollute the atmosphere with plastics and recycled so that the economy can grow.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – As shadow rapporteur at ECON, I too have been involved in more detail on single-use plastics, and it is true what my colleagues are saying: we are drowning in plastic, we use it even where its use makes no sense, no sustainable reason, except that the market has created this need.  I believe that there is too little emphasis on education in this directive. Habits can be changed, but not overnight, and that is why I would like us to raise awareness more, learn about the damage we are doing to the environment.  It may be inconceivable today that most of the population would abandon unnecessary disposable plastic packaging, but let me remind you, even sometimes we have driven unfit in cars, but this is different today. It wasn't the punishment that helped, it was the extensive campaign.  Despite all the shortcomings, I am, of course, in support of the directive and I am pleased that on Wednesday we will take a step forward in a vote to move forward.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Plastic waste comes largely from Africa and Asia. Up to ten rivers are involved in a total of 10 rivers, which flush the plastic waste into the seas. But I think that the rubbish also comes from some direction. This is also about the responsibility of the suppliers, who produce this waste and who would then have to be involved in it in order to prevent this waste accordingly. There could be manufacturers who sail through the most polluted seas by boat and collect the plastics for recycling, turn plastics into fuel and use them as fuel. Technically, it is possible. In this respect, on the one hand, product liability at the manufacturer's, but then we also have to look at the extent to which the plastic islands, which are already there, which soon make up a continent in the Pacific, can then be re-transformed and dismantled.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, plastic can be a great invention, but it turns into our nightmare over time. In my opinion, the issue of the environmental impact of plastic products is still under-addressed. At present, we are literally inundated with tons of plastic, which then end up in the seas and oceans, which is contrary to our efforts to preserve the oceans as such. Europe produces 150,000 tonnes of plastic waste every year, which ends up in the sea. We must take strong action against plastic products, otherwise it will be too late to solve the problem. If we really want to avoid negative environmental impacts, we need to set up a stricter legislative framework. I fully support this policy focusing primarily on single-use plastics. At the same time, one-offs exclude sustainability. We have to deal with plastic bags, straws, plastic cutlery, etc. On the other hand, we need to come up with real measures to replace these funds at the same time. Only environmentally friendly products will allow us to prevent the deterioration of the current situation in the area of plastic waste.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am pleased with the enthusiasm with which you have come forward. I would also like to mention the support that we have in Council from all the Member States. In fact, some countries have already started to reduce the use of single—use plastic products by restricting or banning certain items such as straws. The EU must act now to ensure these diverse actions do not fragment the single market. I would like to clarify the discussion on balloons. Actually the proposal will not ban balloons. It will ban balloon sticks, which are among the most-littered items found on beaches. There are alternatives available on the market, such as wood or cardboard. For balloons, the actions foreseen include information campaigns, voluntary action and labelling. As Mr Florenz and Mr Affronte mentioned, we are working with the industry. We understand that businesses need a level playing field, with clarity and legal certainty and the possibility to develop economics of scale for new markets and alternative materials. The aim is to create market and innovation opportunities for alternative products that are multi-use, but also products made from other materials with less environmental impact. It will boost new business models and offer innovation potential. Tackling marine litter does, therefore, create economic opportunities for Europe. The Commission is committed to leading by example in the creation of a more secular and sustainable plastics economy. I am convinced that together, we will leave a legacy that we can all be proud of. Once again, I would like to thank Ms Ries and the shadow rapporteurs for their ambitious effort.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would once again like to thank the Commissioner for confirming this commitment of the Commission, a collegial and personal commitment as well. We know that of some of its members, I am thinking of Mr. Vella who is with us this evening, but also of Vice-President Mr. Timmermans and Mr. Katainen. I come back to only one point, that of biodegradability, which has been mentioned several times, the solution for some of my colleagues. This is obviously not the way to go, the goal is not to replace a plastic with another plastic. Moreover, there are no reliable or even official standards in the marine environment.  I would like to say this- I will say it this way - not to thank President Wieland: I must point out that in 20 years of presence here, I have never seen a President cut off a rapporteur at the last second of his intervention time. I asked a question, the sound will be proof, I asked a question at the end of my blue card, as well as Mrs Auken. You have unfairly denied me the opportunity to question my colleagues on specific points. This attitude was unfair, Mr President, and biased. In conclusion - no, I can no longer conclude, but it does not matter - I would have told you what I had to say about how you conduct the debates.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mrs Ries. I would like to point out that I treat everyone exactly the same. You had five minutes to speak, and I always admit a little, including rapporteurs, and I finally interrupted you at five minutes and 25 seconds.  It is also a question of collegiality that we do not allow colleagues who are still on the agenda to wait too long. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 24 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The problem of disposable plastic packaging polluting the environment, especially marine packaging, is an important environmental challenge. However, I believe that it should be tackled systematically and not on a prohibition basis. And most importantly, with common sense. The proposal presented, in my opinion, contains shortcomings and harmful provisions, often imprecise and disproportionate to the situation, which is the reason for the 8 amendments I tabled. It completely ignores the issue of food hygiene, which is a great achievement in the use of SUP (single use plastics) compared to the past. It is also incomprehensible to apply different rules to SUP and plastic bottles, foil and plastic packaging, which are the main source of long-term environmental pollution. It is not true that the Commission and some MePs have said that the proposed proposal will be neutral for employment in the European Union and will only cover products from China. In the EU, there is a large industry with numerous employees producing, in addition to plastic, environmentally friendly disposable paper, cardboard or advanced products – with an admixture of plastics, aluminium and waxed paper. This industry must not be liquidated. The insufficient project addresses the problem of effective recycling, which would create new jobs rather than reduce them. The proposed Directive should act as a motivating feature for multinationals responsible for which plastics they choose to packaging their products in order to encourage them to use green substitutes.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – The Directive on reducing the impact of certain plastic products on the environment aims to reduce the environmental impact of disposable plastics while promoting the transition to a circular economy with innovative and multifunctional alternatives. In Europe, around 150,000 tonnes of plastic waste end up in the sea every year, and the trend is steeply upwards, half of which are disposable goods and a quarter are fishing gear. Plastic waste is increasingly becoming a threat to ecosystems and biodiversity, to human health, to tourism, fisheries and shipping. However, the waste problem is cross-border, with 18 of the 20 largest marine polluters being emerging economies. Large-scale measures to filter waste from the world's oceans are costly and not yet effective, so ways can be found to prevent plastic from entering the seas in the first place. This is what this directive is intended to achieve. Companies will incur compliance costs of EUR 2 billion and waste management of EUR 510 million as a result of the implementation of the Directive. The Commission does not provide any information on the implementation costs of extended producer responsibility, and therefore particular attention must be paid to the principle of proportionality. The vast majority of companies in the plastics processing industry are small and medium-sized enterprises and they need time to develop and introduce new products.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – Global plastic production has increased twentyfold since the 1960s and is expected to double over the next twenty years. Some estimates suggest there will be more plastic waste by 2050 than fish in the oceans if we do not take urgent action. Limiting plastic pollution is necessary to keep beaches and the sea clean, while protecting the health of European citizens from the negative impact of marine litter that breaks down in the water and ends up on our table. On the other hand, this is also an economic opportunity, both to reduce the loss of valuable resources from the single use of plastic materials and to improve the quality of tourism services. I therefore support measures to encourage the shift towards cleaner alternative products that are spaising nature and human health, as well as increasing the recycling and recovery of plastic waste. However, all responsibility for pollution and prevention cannot be passed on to producers alone. Education, raising awareness of the negative consequences and changing public attitudes towards disposal, as well as improving infrastructure play no less of a role.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Plastic properties have enabled significant improvements in food quality, as well as in the transport, medicine or construction sector, but at the same time they are creating one of the main problems facing humanity along with climate change. The lack of waste management policies for their separate treatment and the lack of co-responsibility of packers has led us to the current point where it ends up in the oceans almost half a ton of plastic garbage per second, an amount that is chillingly increasing. With the excuse of making affordable products available to consumers, no one pays the environmental costs that this garbage generates and will continue to generate for centuries, in the form of microplastics. The problem is greater when we talk about single-use plastics, designed to use and pull, creating unsustainable consumption habits that must be tackled, especially when there are biodegradable alternatives. European industry has an opportunity to be a benchmark and leader in the abandonment of single-use plastics. This Directive is the first of many steps the EU must take to achieve a real circular economy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – Plastics are responsible for 85% of ocean waste. From Europe, 150,000 tonnes of plastic end up in the ocean every year. But statistics on the impact of one unit of waste are also frightening. For example, a single cigarette filter can pollute 500 to 1,000 liters of water. I support the ban on products for which we already have more gentle alternatives. For other products, there will be still work to be done to develop alternatives before they can be banned. At the same time, I believe that the amount of plastic contained in the product should be taken into account when implementing the measures of the Directive. It is unfortunate that both the proposal for a directive and the committee's report do not take into account the differences in the amount of plastic contained. While products may be required to invest in alternatives and share in the costs of waste collection, these obligations must be proportionate. I therefore welcome the relaxation of the liability system and the addition of the Commission's obligation to develop guidelines to assist Member States in the application of the producer responsibility system and (perhaps) to prevent excesses.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Krzysztof Hetman's report on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the employment and social policies of the euro area (2018/2034(INI)) (A8-0329/2018).

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Looking at the latest data on the growth of the European economy, you can be optimistic. They clearly indicate that we have taken the wind in our sails. Improvements are seen in areas such as public finances, employment and investment. The unemployment rate in the euro area was 8.6% at the beginning of 2018 and is the lowest since the economic crisis. The overall employment rate in the euro area, which stood at 71% last year, is also encouraging, showing that we are approaching the 75% employment target set by the Europe 2020 strategy.  Despite these positive signals, however, we must remember that there are still many areas that require us to intervene urgently and efficiently. The share of unemployed young people in the euro area remains close to 17% The rate of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion is also very high, which is currently just over 23% in the euro area, or almost 120 million people, which means that it is still higher than in 2009. Segmentation and inequalities in the labour market also persist. The above data means one thing: our efforts to combat these negative phenomena must be stepped up. Our aim should be an integrated labour market that provides high-level employment for all, including disadvantaged groups.  Therefore, reforms in the Member States should promote responsible labour contracts and adequate social protection, including for workers with non-standard and new types of contracts. Dynamically changing forms of employment, as well as digital transformation, require us to adapt accordingly. Workers who should be equipped with the right skills must also respond to the changing demands of the labour market. Therefore, our education systems should be better linked to the labour market, as well as lifelong learning should be promoted. We must also facilitate labour mobility and entry and return to the labour market. We also need a better work-life balance policy so that workers can adapt to employers' expectations without sacrificing their personal lives. To achieve this, flexible workplace arrangements, favourable parental leave for both parents, as well as investing in affordable and good quality childcare should be introduced. Efforts to combat poverty and social exclusion and unfair working conditions, which spoil the market and lead to poverty also among working people, are also needed. I believe that this year's Commission's country-specific recommendations are going in this direction, but I am concerned about their erratic implementation. Since the beginning of the European Semester, only 9% of all recommendations have been implemented in their entirety, while as many as 30% of the recommendations have been implemented in a very limited or not at all manner. In the meantime, I am convinced that better implementation of the recommendations to the Member States would in real terms lead to increased growth and employment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – In many respects, the area of social and employment has been neglected for a long time, so I am pleased that, even by having a separate report, we are paying more attention to this area.  Although, as has already been said, we can be satisfied with the reduction in unemployment, especially of young people, there remains one very big challenge in the labour market, and this challenge is how to reconcile supply and demand.  Technological progress, digitalisation, globalisation represent to us completely new expectations of employee competence, and this is not followed quickly enough by education systems. In addition to the content, the tracking of development also means different legal-formal forms of employment relationships and adaptation of the social security system to these new forms.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on the report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, which is for the first time ing its own separate report on employment and social policies in the euro area. This report contains important elements that must be taken seriously by the Commission. After all, employment and social aspects are a key element of economic and social cohesion within the European Union.
