However, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my disappointment that certain political forces in this European Parliament are putting the markets above the European citizen and I find their attitude incomprehensible to me. I experienced it in another report on policies in the euro area. They did not insist on setting macroeconomic conditions for access to cohesion funds and many other things, which do not help the European project.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the violent fiscal adjustment and austerity imposed in recent years within the euro area have resulted in recession, increased unemployment and, of course, this will have a very serious impact on pension systems in all Member States.  In Greece in particular, the troika turned my country into a social cemetery, cutting pensions by 40%, with a third of pensioners living on less than 600 euros gross per month. With the PSI, which broke up the insurance funds, and while the government had the opportunity to recapitalise the insurance funds, it did not do so. Now, they are attacking pensions and threatening the Eurogroup to cut pensions again from 01/01/2019. We say hands off pensions. Greek pensioners have been impoverished. They can't afford any more cuts.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, we have only been given a brief presentation to discuss employment in the euro area. European citizens need a safe job. The figures in the Hetman report show this. I am pleased that with my amendment we have been able to say that social objectives must have the same priority as economic ones.  But the Conservatives have not accepted any real reforms to tackle unemployment, i.e. no European insurance against unemployment, no stabilisation mechanism through investment, not even a study on the relationship between employment and growth. European citizens, look carefully at the positions of the parties, because on the crucial issue of unemployment it seems that there are two opposite poles on the left and right.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank My colleague Hetman for a very good draft report. While it is encouraging that the current EU economy is growing and we are getting to pre-crisis levels. Moreover, I would point out that at the beginning of 2018, the lowest unemployment rate in the euro area since 2008 was even measured, namely by 8.6%. However, I would like to point out that we should not focus solely on positive indicators, which perhaps show, in a slightly distorted way, that in many respects we have restarted our economic performance. In my opinion, these indicators do not adequately reflect all the circumstances. But it is true that unemployment differs not only from state to state, but is different, especially if we compare the different regions of the Member States. Moreover, the EU still has plenty of room for improvement in the market for youth unemployment, women or successful participation, e.g. immigrants in the labour market. The response to globalisation, digitalisation is still insufficient and many workers are indeed vulnerable. I would therefore be very cautious in these areas. This is closely linked to the financing of cohesion policy, which helps to grow even the most backdeering regions.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, by investing in social rhetoric, the report rightly advocates working with rights and respect for private life, combating unemployment and the generalisation of part-time and temporary contracts, the need for protection against poverty and social exclusion. However, with positive statistical developments in some cases merely marginal, it omits any criticism of the policies of precariousness and low wages that in Portugal, as a little throughout Europe, have increased, launders and omits the contribution of the European Semester and its country-specific recommendations on the degradation of working conditions and increased exploitation. The cynicism and hypocrisy of the text are exposed in the harsh criticism stemming from the European Commission's rise in the minimum wage or a so-called difficulty in laying off workers on fixed-term contracts in Portugal. And it makes clear the necessary rupture with the constraints of the euro and the European Union that prevent the effective valorization of workers, their wages and rights.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, after our hard labour in adopting and promoting the European Pillar of Social Rights, today the time has come to discuss the social and employment aspect of the euro area. A well-designed social market economy is essential for Europe, and in particular for a good functioning monetary union. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Hetman, for putting this aspect forward in the report we have discussed today. We share your analysis of recent socioeconomic developments. It is in line with our findings in the annual Employment and Social Developments in Europe review. The economic conditions are favourable. With 239 million people in employment, employment is at its highest level ever. Unemployment in the euro area is now standing at 8.1%, the lowest since November 2008. We also share the opinion that there is still room for improvement. With the roadmap for deepening the EMU from December 2017 the Commission clearly set the objectives to address this. We stand for more jobs, growth, investment, social fairness and macroeconomic stability. We cannot have a robust economy without well-performing employment and social policies: both are two sides of the same coin, as we know. These policies are at the heart of the European Pillar of Social Rights and their development should lead to a stronger European Monetary Union (EMU). Hence, improving economic resilience requires us to invest in people, invest in the skills of workers throughout their working life. That is why we have launched and are implementing the New Skills Agenda. We live in a fast-moving economy that requires us to adapt. We have to be skilled and re—skilled on a continuous basis. Lifelong learning is not just a buzzword. It is a necessity.  To ensure that workers get protection and the relevant information about their job: that is what our proposal on transparent and predictable working conditions for all workers calls upon. To give everyone the possibility to combine their professional and personal lives: Our proposal on work-life balance calls for better working arrangements and compensated leave for parents and carers. As you know, these last two are legislative proposals still in negotiations between Parliament and the Council. We count on your support to reach an agreement soon. Legislation, however, is not the only instrument to have for stronger employment and social policies in the European Union and a more resilient EMU. The implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights by Member States is crucial to reaching this objective and the instrument to have to monitor and gauge progress is the European Semester.  When zooming in on the euro area, the Pillar is already fully integrated into the dedicated recommendation adopted in November last year. It asks Member States to focus on reforms that promote job creation, equal opportunities, accessibility to labour market, fair working conditions and support social protections. To conclude, let me stress that building a strong European economy and a resilient monetary union can only be sustainable through support and investment in our people. This requires well-functioning labour markets and social protection systems. In this light, we can only welcome and share the policy priorities indicated in your report.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – In particular, solidarity and the elimination of social and property inequalities in society should be emphasised in the development of these policies. The economic situation and employment can currently be assessed positively in most euro area countries. Nevertheless, many challenges and inequalities remain in this area. These relate, for example, to the gender pay gap, the significantly different wages for equal work in individual Member States, or youth unemployment. This therefore requires concrete solutions which, in view of the reluctance to share their competences in the social sphere, remain in the hands of the representatives of the nation states. The relatively low unemployment rate we are witnessing today is so important, but it cannot be the final target that is wanted. There is a need to focus more on creating sustainable and quality jobs for an appropriate assessment or to ensure full application for many disadvantaged groups, including disabled fellow citizens. In particular, supranational companies operating in the European Union should also be encouraged to participate in bringing wage levels across Member States closer to speed. Their investments are usually accompanied by large-scale government incentives. The principle of equal pay for equal work should be their condition.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - The report on employment policy and social policy of the euro area speaks of the youth unemployment rate, which remains unacceptably high and higher than twice the overall unemployment average, with approximately one in three young people unemployed in some countries.  The economic recovery remains uneasy across the euro area and there remains significant room for improvement in terms of economic convergence, the fight against youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, gender imbalances, labour market segmentation and inequality, in particular for vulnerable groups, as well as in terms of reducing the number of people working below their qualification level, reducing poverty in general, in particular in employment poverty, eradicating child poverty and boosting productivity and wage growth.  The report, which I voted for, notes that Member States should implement reforms, as supported by the Commission, as part of country-specific recommendations, and should focus them in particular on policies that increase productivity and the potential of sustainable growth so that the whole EU goes together towards decent jobs, access to social protection, regardless of employment relationship or type of contracts , and wage growth that has a significant impact on reducing inequalities, the risk of poverty and social exclusion, and contribute to improving living standards and supporting economic recovery.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The debate on employment and social policies of the euro area in the European Parliament on 22/10/2018 paints an optimistic and truncated picture of employment. He forgets to point out that unemployment is twice as high in the eurozone (8.3%) countries (4.2%). It highlights Germany, but can we believe its unemployment statistics (3.4%) in June 2018 as only 5% of the 1.2 million refugees who arrived in 2015-16 are working full-time in 2017. This means that more than one million people are removed from the unemployment figures. Meanwhile, in the euro area 1 in 2 unemployed has been unemployed for more than a year and 10% of workers are poor. As a solution, the report calls for more and more structural reforms and "inclusion." Integration of migrants and refugees into the labour market would thus be one of the three solutions to the maintenance of pension systems. Worse, the majority parties (EPP, ALDE, S-D) have rejected our employment priority amendments for European citizens and unemployed. This confirms that Brussels does not want to build a great Europe but a world in small.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the day is the brief presentation of Renate Weber's report on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the role of employee participation in job creation and the reintegration of the unemployed into the labour market (2018/2053(INI)) (A8-0293/2018).

name: Renate WEBER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the shadows for our excellent cooperation on this file. Employee financial participation (EFP) is one possible way to achieve our goal to reduce unemployment and ensure sustainable growth and jobs. It has been proved that the social performance of a company that has employee share ownership is 52% higher than in companies which have neither employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs) nor an employee saving plan. Currently, there are some 10 million employee shareholders in Europe and 20 Member States have some sort of EFP incentive regulation. Nevertheless, the development of EFP is geographically unbalanced within the European Union with a lag of 30 to 40 years between the lead and the late European countries. The explanation resides in the existence or not of adequate legislation and frameworks. In spite of many recommendations that have been issued since 1991, not much has been done in terms of approaching the topic at EU level through legislation or comprehensive public policies.  Therefore this report aims at creating momentum again for EFP by, first of all, emphasising the potential of these schemes for both workers and their employers. Among the advantages of EFP schemes, I can mention more sustainable governance, better business continuity and access to capital for SMEs, better social dialogue and quality of work, more fidelity and motivation, less absenteeism and better skills development.  Secondly, the report stresses the risks and the loopholes which need to be tackled while developing EFP. We must provide guarantees to protect employees and companies alike. Each EFP scheme should offer a wide range of tools for the company to design the most relevant scheme according to their size or activity. At the same time, any EFP scheme must be developed with social partners, employees and relevant stakeholders. It must remain voluntary for employees and should be based on their informed consent, fully aware of their entitlements, obligations and risks. Training should be offered to the employees in this respect. The EFP should never replace salaries and no discrimination should ever be accepted relating to the employee’s decision to join these schemes or not.  Thirdly, the report suggests a number of measures which could be taken at Union level. The Commission and Member States should design frameworks for the development of such schemes throughout Europe, they should promote financial education, raise awareness among companies and employees and look into developing fiscal incentives for companies which would like to expand transnationally. Synergies should be developed with programmes and for efforts carried out by the Commission whose aim is to improve access to capital, especially for SMEs. We mention the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, COSME and the social economy, but also encourage different DGs to work together, like DG Employment, DG FISMA and DG GROW.  I hope that Parliament’s vote will this time be followed by a proper action on behalf of the Commission.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the report refers to the involvement of employees in the management and profits of enterprises as a way of increasing pay. But what about wages in the countries of the European South? In Greece, the memorandums reduced the minimum wage, and even provided for a sub-minimum wage, which is lower for young people under the age of 25. So hunger wages are the ones that prevail in Greece and have impoverished the Greek people. Salaries in the public sector, and in the private sector of course, were also slashed, while in the public sector gifts were abolished.  One realizes that there is a situation of work jungle today in Greece, with companies leaving thousands of unpaid workers, with companies that refuse to insure workers, with companies that do not pay the wages, but many of them force workers to be paid in kind. Disgrace! The working jungle, the working age in Greece, must be stopped.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, shares in workers, profit participation, wage-productivity link, individual and group agreements on production bonuses, cooperative enterprises, a solidarity economy, all of this is a carrot that is being whipped into the abolition of collective agreements, wage increases, strike action and all other labour rights. In Greece, the neo-left SYRIZA government voted again on the memorandum law abolishing collective agreements, the dependence of wages on profits. Capitalists, of course, are not content with them, they want to manipulate workers to make them part of their own exploitation, with social dialogues and the betrayal of the government's employers' union to die their movement. These mean endless hours of unpaid work, exhaustive intensification in the pursuit of targets, resignation of increases, collective action and claim, loss of employment insurance funds in the event of bankruptcy. Business profits presuppose barbaric exploitation of workers, not in keeping with their well-being. Only organized class struggle, aiming to overthrow the exploitative system, can today defend and permanently enshrine labour rights.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, workers' shareholding in some Western countries has proven to be a quality model that further motivates workers and brings them stable earnings in addition to wages. Unfortunately, in countries like Croatia, such a model proved to be well unsuccessful because workers are not used to taking care of the company as their own property. The best example is the Uljanik shipyard, which is about to collapse, where workers hold 47% of the shares. After becoming owners of a large part of the company, they did not change the way they functioned before, but treated the company the same as before.  In order for this model to be successful throughout the European Union, countries that have adopted a market economy relatively recently need a change of mentality and strengthening the independence of the judiciary. Only then can we expect a uniform development of labour shareholding throughout Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the participation of employees in the management of enterprises and in the share capital of enterprises is one of the factors that can contribute to the development of the economy.  Where an employee has a share in the share capital, he has an incentive to work more efficiently, to build on his qualifications and to contribute to the viability of the undertaking, which he regards as a family business. Therefore, in this sense it is positive, in theory at least, for an employee to be involved in the share capital of an undertaking, as well as in the management of the undertaking. What is contradictory is the practical application of all these measures. Unfortunately in Greece it has been shown that none of this is true. All family businesses, especially small businesses, have been destroyed and there is no possibility of surviving unfortunately afterwards.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this constructive discussion and for your valuable remarks. I take note of your recommendations and of your commitment to the development and promotion of employee financial participation schemes in the European Union.  Research on the various forms of employee financial participation has pointed out the potential benefits, as well as the risks, associated with these schemes for both workers and companies. The studies carried out in previous years show how employee financial participation schemes can increase the competitiveness of companies. In particular, they can increase workers’ income and their identification with the companies they are working at. As such, these schemes may improve the job satisfaction of employees and contribute to improving the relationship between the employer and the employees. At the same time, employee financial participation schemes can increase the financial vulnerability of individual workers. It is therefore crucial to prevent unreasonable risks when designing and running these schemes. Sufficient information should be provided to employees about the details of the schemes and any risks involved. Importantly, employee financial participation schemes should be seen as complementing their fixed wage. Employee financial participation may therefore be a subject of normal negotiations between social partners dealing with wage setting and working conditions without replacing them. Therefore I welcome the report’s calls for engagement with social partners on this subject. Progress on workers’ financial participation will not only depend on supportive legal framework conditions in the Member States but also on the appetite of social partners to engage further in this area.  The Commission promotes participatory forms of corporate governance in different ways, for instance as part of the actions under the Small Business Initiative and by means of the Employment and Social Innovation Programme. As regards employee financial participation in particular, the Commission encourages Member States to exchange best practices in order to spread the information about how to design efficient schemes.  This concerns in particular the design of taxation regimes in Member States, which your report rightly identifies as one of the principal challenges financial participation faces. Financial participation, and more specifically employee share ownership, is also important to revive equity culture in Europe. Individuals having access to a securities account through their employers-employee share ownership scheme can familiarise themselves with capital markets and foster retail investments in the EU, once the core areas of capital markets union. That is why, in the 2017 mid-term review of the Capital Markets Union Action Plan, the Commission proposed to develop and promote best practices for employee share ownership schemes to provide an opportunity for individuals to get familiar with capital markets, giving a first insight into equity investment.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 23 October 2018.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: Romana TOMC
text: – All media, and especially those in the public domain, would be expected to provide people with objective and balanced information.  It is unacceptable for banners with death threats to be shown on public television by members of the opposition party to try to stop broadcasts that reveal to people the history that the former Communist regime denies, that journalists seeking the truth are subject to threats and prosecutions. All this is unfortunately a reality in Slovenia.  The reality is also that most journalists are caught up in the job, perhaps also in order to be more obedient. I also reject in the sharpest way public calls for the silencing of the other-minded and the misuse of the public media for political purposes. I therefore call on the Presidency and my colleagues in Parliament to speak openly and with the same criteria about media freedom in all Member States.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, sadly we seem to live in an era where too much casual prejudice and serious hatred finds its way into public discourse, particularly online. So I want to pay tribute today to organisations working with young people to help tackle that hate: organisations like Leicester’s Federation of Muslim Organisations, who I recently joined for their Eid celebrations; the Holocaust Education Trust, this year marking 30 years of profoundly important work; and the National Holocaust Centre, which is based in my constituency. These organisations and many more do incredibly important and special work, because they are equipping young people with the tools, with the knowledge, to help tackle that hate. And young people have a unique role and unique potential to help us tackle that hate, and all of us in this Parliament have a responsibility to stand alongside those young people in confronting and tackling hatred in our society.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, a very serious and horrific crime happened in Bulgaria a few days ago – a young lady was killed in an extremely brutal way. And here in this institution, in the European Parliament Chamber, the people who speak most against fake news have started spreading and creating fake news. Chairmen of parliamentary groups, commissioners rushed to link this murder to the work of the victim and declare him a murder for the reason of the occupation of the victim, who is a journalist. After it was revealed that the murder was committed by a criminal – a Bulgarian citizen of Gypsy origin – not a single apology followed, but should have happened. For three years now, we've been talking about fake news, about not allowing such fake news, and it's in this room that people who pretend to fight this fake news are spreading them.  I want every single one of the people who spread this fake news to apologize for it.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr. Chairman, I must admit that I do not understand anything about the elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the comments of my colleagues here in Parliament regarding President Komsic. What bothers them? It bothers them that the candidate, they say, was chosen not only by Croats but also by some others. Well, let's just say so. Well, isn't that what we've been begging people for 27 years? To act not as ethnics, not as nationalists, but as citizens. And once they act like that, it's like a problem. What else is the problem? Well, he's not Croat enough. He is Croat, he is not a nationalist. That's what bothers them: that a man is not a nationalist. But nowhere in the Dayton Accords do I see the presidency reserved for nationalists. And third, colleagues don't realize when you support nationalists then you get nationalists, and then you'll complain afterwards that all the nationalists are in Bosnia and Herzegovina. President Komsic must be supported by the European community and he is always welcome here.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, Saudi Arabia is an authoritarian state that I dare not even call medieval, ruled by a corrupt and cruel caste, where terrorism is executed in public, where all, particularly women and outsiders, survive at the mercy of the whim of rulers. There's no need to insist. Journalist Jashogui's heinous death has finally set off some alarms. Germany has announced the suspension of arms sales to the Saudi Government, while inviting the other countries of the Union to do the same. Spain is a major arms exporter and, with the very interested intervention of the King of Spain, has a great customer in Saudi Arabia. From here I call on the Spanish Government to unsern the German Government and to suspend its arms sales to that country; that he does not adopt the shameful commercial attitude of the President of the United States and of all those for whom business is more important than life and the defense of human rights. Following Saudi Arabia's trajectory and maintaining friendship with Saudi Arabia means continuing on the path of indignity, of ignominy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the Structural Funds are never, ever, an expression of supposed European solidarity. They are, yes, and always have been, a monetary compensation for the asymmetric impact of integration. If there are those who win with the single market, the euro and common policies, there are also those who lose and some people lose a lot. This is why this form of compensation is insufficient and interesting, and it is in the light of this reality that the proposals for structural fund regulations put forward by the European Commission are extremely worrying. Unless amended, these proposals mean more difficulties in using the smallest available money, meaning that the application of these funds will be subject not to the interests and needs of each State, especially those facing greater difficulties, but rather subject to the political objectives set by the main powers in defending their own interests, their multinationals, including in the area of the arms industry.  That is why they want to quickly approve these regulations without involvement and public discussions. That is why it is also necessary to denounce and combat this intention.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to draw your attention to the institute's activities under the name Transport and Environment, funded, among other things, by the european taxpayer's money, with european commission money. This institute produces such nonsensical reports, in which, for example, it describes with regret how Poles import diesel cars from western Europe, looking at some environmental damage. Well I do not understand. If these cars exist and drive in Germany, what environmental damage does it mean that they will now drive in Poland? The report also regrets, for example, that poorer Europeans in the east in general buy second-hand cars. As they buy used ones, it is better, because some environmental resources have been used to produce these cars, and instead of wasting, they will serve the poorer. And insulting the poor that they are poor is really idiotic. We are also playing with the money of the European taxpayer, producing such crappy reports.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Millions of people are currently being held in camps in China and systematically killed, slaughtered on order, because the Chinese government is engaged in illegal and inhumane organ theft. And Europe is looking away. In its latest study, the China Organ Harvest Research Centre speaks of organ transplant on demand – organs on demand. It is the same. In China, you wait an average of just two weeks for a new organ if you are rich, even shorter. By comparison, in Germany it is six to eight years. And at whose expense? Religious minorities such as Christians, hundreds of thousands of Falun Gong, ethnic minorities such as tibetans or Uighurs are also led to the slaughterhouse for Europeans. Thousands of them lose their lives every month on order – mass murder. I call on this House, the Commission, the Council and the External Representative, Mr Mogherini, to save lives. European values require action! Sanctions against China are urgently needed here.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, the Spanish State uses every way imaginable to prevent Catalan citizens from exercising democracy for free determination: police and judicial repression, state sewers and now we know that economic warfare too. An interesting work by the newspaper Ara brought to light how after the referendum, which the Spanish state tried to avoid, state administrations and public companies massively withdrawn funds from the two large Catalan banks as a pressure measure to move their headquarters outside Catalonia. This irresponsibility led to the fall in the shares of these banks and caused a systemic risk hazard that could have seriously affected the Catalan, Spanish and European economy.  The European Commission should investigate these political maneuvers on financial institutions, manoeuvres that had a clear objective of deliberately destabilizing a country's economy as punishment for having had a vote and decision.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, the multinational Alcoa has announced unilaterally and without any negotiation the closure of the avilés and A Coruña factories and, with it, the destruction of seven hundred direct and many other indirect jobs. Plants are productive and have benefits, as union representatives stand out. That is why the multinational must be required to withdraw the closing dossier and open a negotiating table to find formulas to ensure the maintenance of employment and its future viability. But the Spanish Government must also take action, ensuring a stable energy model that prevents abusive electricity prices, set through auction. There are many measures that can be taken in energy matters, but without a doubt the most beneficial for the industrial sector and for the public sector would be that this strategic sector is in the hands of the public authorities. It should be remembered that without industry there is no future or quality jobs. Alcoa doesn't close!

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Mr. Chairman, I am very concerned about the outcome of the elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the possible consequences based on the first reactions of individual elected officials in Sarajevo. As a member of the European Union and as guarantor of the Dayton-Paris Peace Agreement, Croatia will continue to closely monitor the development of the situation in this country and its impact on peace and stability. Encouraged by Mogherini and Han's statement to respect the decision of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Ljubic case in the formation of the House of Peoples, I think it is high time to pass an electoral law, so that Bosnia and Herzegovina avoids a deepening crisis. Any further reckless support by actors who support the two extremes, centralisation and separatism, leads to the polarization of the country. I call for a final consideration of the position of the third constituent community, which throughout history has always chosen the middle ground between the two extremes mentioned and led the country in Euro-Atlantic integration. One nation has been stripped of their rights, due to a series of changes to electoral law over the past two decades. I believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina can overcome existing problems.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Moody's has downgraded Italy's public debt to one step above the level of rubbish. Tomorrow, the Commission will probably boycott the manoeuvre, as has been murmuring for days. I say this with sincerity: I am not worried about how much the deficit-to-GDP ratio is overrun, france and Germany have already done so before us. What worries me is the objectives, the lack of investment and compliance with European rules. Italy must reduce public debt, create jobs and growth, reduce social gaps. The signs coming in these hours are dramatic: waste of resources, less employment, greater inequalities. An entire generation will spend their lives with the burden of public debt on their shoulders, all because of the choices of a government that cannot go beyond propaganda. Richer and richer, poorer and poorer, in a nation that is now isolated in Europe and in the world. The first to condemn Italy today is Sebastian Kurz, an ally of the pentastellate government. Congratulations! I address my fellow Members from the 5 Star Movement and the League: history will remind you of you as the ruling class that destroyed the future of our young people. Politics is measured by results, not by the bombastic announcements to which you have become accustomed... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – In Slovakia as well as in the Czech Republic, we are celebrating an important anniversary 100 years since the establishment of the common state of Czechs and Slovaks, i.e. Czechoslovakia. I consider it important to remember this here in the European Parliament as well. After the First World War, the state of two Slavic peoples rose from the ruins of the multinational Habsburg Monarchy, so the Slovaks had their own state, in which they could use their mother tongue without restriction, develop cultural heritage and freely decide on social functioning on their territory. Of course, our coexistence has not been smooth either, but in 70 years we have proved many times that we can resolve our conflicts with peace and debate. It is the division of both of our states in peace that came in the early 1990s that can be seen as the greatest evidence of this special relationship. It is at this time that it has become clear in other parts of Europe that hatred, extreme nationalism and violence can simply infect people's hearts. I think that, even today, we can take an example from Czechoslovakia, because together we face many problems, whether from across borders or from within the Union, and we should not be blamed and punished.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, what is it about the provision of rural broadband that it seems to attract repeated failures and controversies? This month in Ireland yet another Minister left the Department with responsibility for broadband, this time forced out due to unethical engagements with bidders for the billion-euro National Broadband tender. The Commission too has serious questions to answer as to why a Luxembourg-based corporation was selected without public procurement process to manage a multi-million euro EU fund while they were also bidding to take over an Irish company involved in the National Broadband bid. The reason for the controversies and the repeated failures is that broadband provision has been seen by both the EU and the Irish Government as, rather than a public service, one which has instead been placed in the hands of private corporate interests whose first interest, at all stages, is their own profits. The losers in all of this are, of course, the people of those rural communities that do not have access to broadband. It’s time for a public ownership model of telecommunications infrastructure to take precedence so that finally, everyone will have access to this essential infrastructure.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to follow up with my honourable colleague Mr Škripek. I also wanted to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of Czechoslovakia. I would like to point out that it is at the end of this week that we will commemorate this verbal anniversary with the participation of French President Emmanuel Macron and also German Chancellor Angela Merkel.  This is an extraordinary moment for our country to commemorate the role of the first president of a free and democratic Czechoslovakia, Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, on October 28th. Their amazing vision of a free state, the goal they went to with a well-thought-out plan, are truly a demonstration of their statesmanship. Their work, which, despite its staggering difficulties, has overcome all the calamities of the 20th century, also provides our generation with the much-valued values of freedom, a democracy in which even an individual is important and has its place and irreplaceable value. Their vision has fallen apart, but they continue to work together in the EU. At the same time, I must recall that the men on October 28th have quite consciously connected with Western democracies. Unfortunately, the subsequent historical development after 1948 ripped out Czechoslovakia... (removed the speaker's word)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, 2018 is the European Year of Cultural Heritage. However, unfortunately, in a part of the European Union, in the northern occupied part of Cyprus, where I too come from and became a refugee after the invasion of Turkey in 1974, in that northern part a treasure trove of our European culture is still being destroyed today. Hundreds of churches have been looted, thousands of Byzantine icons have been stolen. The pleasant thing, however, is that in recent days, Mr President, we have learned after surprise in Cyprus that two thousand Byzantine icons are captured in the Castle of Kyrenia where I come from and I was born too. In that, then, the castle is part of our European culture and we expect the European Union to take the appropriate steps to give it back to the Church of Cyprus.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, we are seeing these last few days truly painful images, images of thousands of people, mainly Honduran and Honduran, fleeing violence in one of the most dangerous regions of the world. There are women, children, the elderly, unaccompanied minors, thousands of people who have no other purpose than to reach the United States and seek asylum—a universal right.  A few months ago we were shocked by American immigration policy, with the detention and separation of families. Trump now threatens to suspend aid to countries of origin that do not act as border policemen and send the Army to stop this caravan of immigrants. In the face of all this, the European Union does not do or say anything. The European Union must send an observation mission and provide financial aid to alleviate the humanitarian crisis we are seeing. We can't keep looking the other way.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to express my concern about the recent atrocities of the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia. Minority restrictions, education and then language laws create uncertainty, made worse by a sense of security. Some are consciously working to break the peace between nationalities in Transcarpathia. Hungarians have been presented negatively in the media for some time, and they are wrongly accused of separatism. An extremist website began listing Transcarpathians as enemies of the people as intimidation, publishing personal information. This violates not only Ukraine's existing legislation, but also international standards, but this page has not been blocked. On the Website of the Supreme Council there is a petition collecting signatures for the deportation of Hungarians from Transcarpathia. It's incitement against the community, but it's still registered. At the weekend, unknown people put up billboards with the words "Stop the separatists", abusing the photos and names of Hungarian leaders in Transcarpathia. The inaction of the Ukrainian authorities and the indifference of European politics leave room for these ethnic-based provocations, attempts at destabilisation and tensions for political gain ...  (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, climate change continues to cause considerable damage. Once again, southern Italy, in particular Calabria, is affected, paying a very high price, also in terms of loss of life, for the lack of protection of the territory and the hydrogeological failure. I was in Calabria, in Lamezia Terme, during the hours when the torrential rains fell and I saw for myself the damage caused in the agricultural sector, to infrastructure, to farm and rural structures that must be restored as soon as possible so as not to further compromise the fragile economic fabric that exists. Italy is now cyclically the victim of environmental disasters and urgently needs a general plan for the prevention and security of the territory. The direct and indirect funds provided by the European Union to combat climate change cannot be enough. Investments to secure the territories affected by the unforeseen climate change disasters must be allocated to the deficit/GDP calculation.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Last week, the whole world commemorated the 26th anniversary of the announcement of the International Day against Poverty. In this House, we often talk about poverty, especially in relation to third countries. However, poverty, which marginalised people and took away their dignity, also exists in the European Union and is suffered by millions of our families. Poverty is often hereditary. It affects women more than men, because family breakdown is an aggravating burden for many mothers. Conquering poverty means understanding that family ties, especially the presence of a father and mother, are important indicators of a child's well-being. The Union should therefore support those policies of the Member States which seek to strengthen the institution of marriage and the natural family. Unfortunately, in recent years, I feel that it is doing the exact opposite.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, just a few days after the report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was delivered, the Department of Aude, in south-west France, has just experienced unprecedented flooding. I knew the ones of 1992, I experienced the floods of 1999 and I have just experienced them and each time there have been deaths. This time, there were 14 deaths, 16,000 families affected and more than 200 million property damage. There's an emergency! At a time when the United Nations conference is meeting today in Katowice for COP 24, we must remember here that there is an urgent need to act collectively on climate. I would also like to say forcefully that we must review together the European Union Solidarity Fund, and in particular the threshold for triggering this fund, because the further we go, the more these climatic incidents occur in limited areas with unprecedented intensity. These floods in the Aude are historic: we had never reached such thresholds in terms of material and human damage.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament's recent Eurobarometer found that Romanians' confidence in membership of the European Union had fallen from 59% to 49%. Without question, accession to the European Union was the best thing that happened to Romania since 2007. Thus, the more than thirty billion euro non-refundable from the European Union attracted to Romania has had a positive impact on Romanians, increasing the quality of life in all aspects. I appreciate, however, that the decline in confidence in the European Union is solely due to the disastrous governance of the PSD-ALDE. The amendment of the criminal legislation for the benefit of a small group, the lack of European funds for vital projects, the accusations always made by the PSD-ALDE to the European Union to justify their own failures have led to this state of affairs. I draw the attention of this irresponsible PSD-ALDE government that the recent observations from the European institutions, whether we are talking about the European Commission, the European Parliament or the Venice Commission, were made in good faith and to draw attention to the legislative slippages that violated the values of the European Union and were in no way against the Romanians.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, the American multinational Alcoa recently announced the closure of its plants in Avilés and A Coruña and the dismissal of all its workers: 686 broken lives, 686 families in absolute uncertainty by a company that continues to record profits in its incomeability account. That is why I demand from here, from the European Parliament, that this company open a negotiating table with all social actors, with public agents, to avoid closure. And I also ask the Union not to be notary of the intentions of the American company Alcoa and to join the cry of Asturias and Galicia and all of Spain to defend those two plants in our country. We will be fighting, we will avoid this closure and Parliament will be attached to the workers because Alcoa does not close!

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The President of Romania will be a guest of the European Parliament tomorrow. Klaus Johannis won the presidency in 2014 with the support of the PNL, a party family of the European People's Party, and garnered an overwhelming majority of the votes of the Hungarian minority community in Romania, and has since disappointed his voters on numerous occasions. The Romanian Head of State, who has become a representative of the german minority, which has been woefully deplored, has repeatedly signaled his insensitivity to the rights of national minorities. Unfortunately, it has also tried to revoke existing minority rights in order to preserve the amendment of the Administrative Law in the Constitutional Court. Klaus Johannis's mandate as President so far is not proof of the exemplaryness of the Romanian system for the protection of minorities, on the contrary: another pretext for refusing to talk about the real problems of national minorities. A year before the Romanian presidential elections, President Johannis gave the Hungarian minority in Romania no reason to vote for him again.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I believe that it is time for proper information. Let me tell you a few things about the performance of the current Social Democratic and Liberal Government, which makes Romania a factor of economic and social stability in the European Union. Thus, the Romanian economy grew by 4% in the first half of this year compared to the same period in 2017, after an advance of 1.4% in real terms in the second quarter of this year compared to the previous quarter. In its economic forecasts published at the beginning of May, the European Commission mentioned estimates of the growth of Romania's economy in 2018 at 4.5%, and for 2019 it expects an advance of 3.9%. If we add to these performances the fact that the Dăncilă government places a major emphasis on social programmes, namely the absolutely necessary increase in pensions and salaries, I think we can conclude that Romania is on the right track and tends to occupy the seventh position among European states, becoming an important member of the European Union.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a very violent storm struck eastern Sicily last Friday and particularly affected the province of Catania, with countries that were isolated from the flooding of four rivers, houses submerged in water, families evacuated and hundreds of millions of euros in damage, orange crops, artichokes and vegetables of all kinds completely destroyed. Again yesterday a water bomb and a river of mud, boulders and debris fell on Enna, Gela and Catania, with house collapses, cars overwhelmed, companies destroyed and damage still to be estimated, caused by over 50 centimeters of rain falling in a few tens of minutes, that is, half of that fall in a year. Climate change in Sicily is even more evident than elsewhere and Coldiretti, an organization in the agricultural sector, claims that this 2018 was the hottest year since 1800, with 1.8 degrees above the September average. The request for a state of disaster, which has already been made by the local authorities, is not enough. I would ask the Commission to take care to assess the situation and also to intervene with the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes this item.
